results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. 

• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal ("Boston 1 - Join us") or venmo (@boston1dboat).</a>

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1Ll2NR3MZbV3O7ZrmPdZsCbKRaC_G8KKa7lwBUlC59Pk/viewform?c=0&w=1">"Boston 1 e-waiver" 

• Make sure to check our Facebook,</a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab. 
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards. 

• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended. 

• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $5 flat rate. Weekdays $8 flat rate (in after 3pm). More details can be found here: http://bit.ly/1Nxv1lw.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!
results.name: Monday Water training

results.description:
Aurum Restaurant & Boston Ferments are teaming up again for a night of fermentation on Monday, May 9th! Our last workshop was standing room only so we’ve decided to do it again. The night will include a fermented dinner & paired fermented cocktails, a short lecture on the history & culture of fermentation, and a hands-on fermentation demo. 


The evening kicks off with a fermentation-inspired vegetarian kimchi Syrian pie (with gluten free & vegan options) + a selection of sides. We are pairing this meal with a number of locally made fermented drinks served in handmade ceramic cups (which you will take home!) by workshop leader Jeremy Ogusky.

Next, we will have a short lecture on the biological, political, and symbolic 'culture' of fermented foods around the world and we will then learn to make one of the simplest lacto-fermented treats - sauerkraut! 

All participants will finish the workshop with a healthy belly full of fermented foods, the knowledge & confidence to begin fermenting in their kitchen, and a jar full of fermenting kraut. This starter class will cover everything you need to start fermenting on your own: philosopy, preparation and problem-solving. Please join us!

Get your tickets at fermentinginjp.eventbrite.com

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/fermentation-101-workshop-fermented-dinner-drinks-pairing-hosted-by-aurum-restaurant-tickets-22470927148

If you want to learn to ferment AND go home with a handcrafted fermentation crock to create your own sauerkraut, kimchi & pickles in, this is your chance! Our instructor, Jeremy, is a studio potter and creator of the crocks and he will bring a selection of colors to the workshop that you can choose from. Then you can prepare your own sauerkraut in the workshop in your own handmade crock!


**we understand that $45 is a lot to ask for a night's event - if you cannot afford this & are interested in paying what you can + bartering, please be in touch! **

 Have questions about Fermentation 101 Workshop + Fermented Dinner & Drinks Pairing, hosted by Aurum Restaurant? 

Contact Boston Ferments
results.name: Fermentation 101 Workshop + Fermented Dinner & Drinks Pairing

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4

results.description:
You love sports. You love data. You can use the Stattleship API to build great mobile apps, analytics, data visualizations, and more. 


The Stattleship API connects your website, app, chart, and more with a rich, easy-to-access, set of sports stats and accomplishments. We've partnered with Gracenote (formerly SportsDirect) to provide all of our NFL, NBA, and NHL game data. We'll have MLB in the spring, too. Our service is designed for creative fans who want to use Stattleship data to build commercial apps that scale. That's right, we didn't make this data available to you so you could stare at it. Go forth and conquer the world.


We've categorized and quantified player and teams performances into feats that can quickly be compared, contrasted and put into context. Instantly know if a stat is a commonplace occurrence or a record-tying achievement. Build your own great products From the moment you sign up, you'll realize we've done a lot of hard work for you.


In this tutorial, we will show you how to use our R wrapper to access live and up-to-date sports data via the Stattleship API.


---


Bio:


Tanya Cashorali is the Chief Data Officer of Stattleship - a Boston-based sports content and data business that connects brands with sports fans through social media. She is also the founding partner of TCB Analytics - a Boston-based data consultancy. Tanya started her career in the data-rich field of bioinformatics and applied her experience to other data-rich verticals such as telecom, finance and sports. She brings over 10 years of experience in data scientist roles as well as managing and training data analysts. She's helped grow a handful of Boston startups and prior to launching TCB Analytics, she worked as a data scientist at Biogen.
results.name: Tanya Cashorali - Stop scrAPIng sports data, start Stattleshipping!

results.description:
When it comes to designing digital products, wireframing and prototyping are the bread and butter of the user experience (UX) industry. Wireframes are used to show structure, content and functionality, taking into account user needs and user journeys. Prototypes, which can range from lo-fidelity to high-fidelity, are interactive mockups that are a simulation of the final product. Prototypes allow you to pitch ideas, test with users and discover any pitfalls without investing a large amount of time upfront.

In this 3-night workshop, we will use a combination of two great tools — Sketch and Invision — to build wireframes and turn them into clickable prototypes.


Class Schedule

The workshop will take place over three nights:

• Monday May 9th, 6:30 PM - 8:30 PM (in Assembly Bay 1)

• Monday May 16th, 6:30 PM - 8:30 PM (in Assembly Bay 3)

• Monday May 23rd, 6:30 PM - 8:30 PM (in Assembly Bay 1)

Your payment registers you for the entire series.


Takeways

• Best practices for wireframing and prototyping

• Basic understanding of Sketch, a powerful new design program that is quickly becoming the industry go-to

• Learn how to build interactive mockups in InVision, an easy-to-use prototyping tool created for designers, by designers

• Discover the benefits of rapid prototyping, testing with users, sharing early with stakeholders, and iterating on your designs!

*We will be raffling off 2 Sketch licenses, graciously donated by Sketch, at the end of this workshop!



Who should take this class?

This workshop is ideal for designers, product managers, developers and anyone interested in learning more about prototypes. No prior experience is necessary.

All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct. 


Pre-reqs & Preparation

• Notebook & pens/pencils

• Laptop & charger - Mac OS X 10.10+

• Note that Sketch is for Mac only

• Sketch installed on your computer. If you do not currently have Sketch on your computer, you can buy it for $99 or download a free 14-day trial here. (Note: If you are using the free trial, please do not install Sketch until the day before or the day of class to make sure you get the most out of your free trial!)

• An Invision account (free)

Instructors - Amy & Jamie

Amy Chenault  

Amy uses design, research, & passion to help improve the quality of everyday life. In some of her design lives, she’s had the opportunity to collaborate with amazing teams to democratize financial information, and empower individuals through the power of financial literacy (Society of Grownups); give local communities a voice while maintaining a newspaper’s journalistic integrity (Neighborhood Square); find new and innovative ways to get kids moving in the classroom (Pearson); build an entirely new community platform for one of the most robust communities on the Internet (The Huffington Post/AOL). Work she has contributed to has garnered the 2011 Italian national prize for innovation, and a 2014 CODiE nomination for Best Professional Learning Solution for Education.


LinkedIn | Twitter 


Jamie Connor

Jamie works as a User Experience Designer on the Product Management team at Epsilon, a global leader in data-driven marketing. She spends her time creating, testing and iterating on prototypes with the goal of building intuitive and easy to use products.

Previously, she worked as a Front-end Developer designing and building websites and as a Visual Designer on a global marketing team. Jamie studied Graphic Design at Massachusetts College of Art & Design and has been continuously learning ever since. She is excited to help women transition into the tech field and expand their skill set!

LinkedIn | Twitter

Location

A huge thank you to our sponsor, District Hall, for hosting this event! 

District Hall is located at:


75 Northern Avenue 
Boston, MA 02210 
View Google Map

The 5/9 and 5/23 classes will be in the Assembly Bay 1 classroom, while the 5/16 class will be in the Assembly Bay 3 classroom.


Interested in hosting classes? Email us at boston[at]girldevelopit.com!


Where to park

Paid parking is available next to District Hall.


Teaching Assistants

If you are interested in being a teaching assistant, please fill out our volunteer form. TAing is a great way to practice what you know and to get to know members of our community.

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!

results.description:
Hey Kubernauts!  We're excited to annnounce the agenda for the next Kubernetes meetup on May 9th.  Should be some great learnings!

AGENDA:

6:30-6:45  Meet and greet (Pizza and Beer)

6:45-7:30  Ray Tsang,  Developing and deploying Java-based microservices in Kubernetes

7:30-8:30 Diogenes Rettori,  What's new in Kubernetes 1.2

BIOS:

Ray Tsang is a Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform. Ray had extensive hands on cross-industry enterprise systems integration delivery and management experiences during his time at Accenture, managed full stack application development, DevOps, and ITOps. Ray specialized in middleware, big data, and PaaS products during his time at Red Hat while contributing to open source projects, such as Infinispan. Aside from technology, Ray enjoys traveling and adventures.

Twitter: @saturnism

As an OpenShift product manager, Diogenes Guedes Rettori leads the direction for Red Hat's middleware-services strategy. Prior to joining the OpenShift team, Diogenes focused primarily on educating customers on updates and new offerings for Red Hat JBoss Middleware. Diogenes has a strong engineering background having work at companies such as Ericsson and IBM. He is fluent in Portuguese, English and Spanish.

Twitter: @rettori

ABSTRACTS:

Developing and deploying Java-based microservices in Kubernetes

A quick overview on Docker containers, usages, and how to scale up from a single container to a fleet of containers working together with Kubernetes for real-life workloads, such as running java-based applications! Join this session to see how to use Kubernetes to launch, manage, and rolling-upgrade a fleet of Java application instances with session replication.

Kubernetes builds on top of Docker to construct a clustered container scheduling service. Kubernetes enables users to ask a cluster to run a set of containers. The system will automatically pick worker nodes to run those containers on, which we think of more as "scheduling" than "orchestration". Kubernetes also provides ways for containers to find and communicate with each other and ways to manage both tightly coupled and loosely coupled sets of cooperating containers.

In this session, you'll learn: - How to containerize different Java-based microservice workloads using Docker and different build tool plugins - Deploying and managing a fleet of Java-based microservices in Kubernetes - Service discovery 101 in Kubernetes - Perform critical DevOps steps, such as canary, rolling update, roll backs... - Tips and tricks!

What's new in Kubernetes 1.2

I'm sure you are all excited about the fast paced progress Kubernetes is making. On this meetup you will see demos (and a few slides) of some of the newest Kubernetes features, like:

• More nodes

• More pods per node

• Horizontal pod auto-scaling API

• Ingress API

• Job API

• DaemonSet API

• Deployment API

• ConfigMap API

All the demos will be done using the OpenShift all-in-one Image, and the kube client.

Links:

all-in-one Vagrant box (https://www.openshift.org/vm)

kubectl

http://kubernetes.io/docs/getting-started-guides/docker/#download-kubectl
results.name: Java-based microservices in Kubernetes and What's new for 1.2

results.description:
Agenda:

6-6:30pm - News, announcements, job postings, etc.

7-~8pm - Main presentation & Q/A

How to Talk to the C-Level:


When talking with colleagues, we usually have an understanding of what's important and why and may not need to explain it as much. But when talking to C-level management, it might require a different tack, a different way of explaining things. John will tell us ways that he accomplishes this.

John Strand is the owner of Black Hills Information Security, a firm specializing in penetration testing, Active Defense and Hunt Teaming services. He is the also the CTO of Offensive Countermeasures, a firm dedicated to tracking advanced attackers inside and outside your network.

John is an experienced speaker, having done presentations to the FBI, NASA, the NSA and at various industry conferences. He is a senior instructor with the SANS Institute teaching:

SEC504 - Hacker Techniques, Exploits, and Incident Handling
SEC560 - Network Penetration Testing and Ethical Hacking
SEC580 - Metasploit Kung Fu for Enterprise Pen Testing
SEC550 - Offensive Countermeasures, Active Defense and Cyber Deception

And the lead course author of:

SANS 504: Hacker Techniques, Exploits, and Incident Handling

He also co-hosts Security Weekly, the world's largest information security podcast; co-authored Offensive Countermeasures: The Art of Active Defense; and writes loud rock music and makes various futile attempts at fly-fishing.
results.name: How to Talk to the C-Level

Join us for the hippest and hottest workout in town!

results.description:
Whether you are networking to meet potential new clients, learn new tips and techniques from seasoned businesswomen, share ideas and experiences with open and like-minded women or just to meet new friends in the area, this is the group for you.  Bring your marketing materials and business cards to distribute.  We aim to have a member speaker at each gathering, whom I have listed below.  If you would like to give a presentation at one of our meetings, please scroll down to  see if someone has been selected yet.  If not, you may inquire about being our speaker of the evening.  In order to speak, your membership dues must be current and you may pay your dues online or at your next meeting.  

Happy chatting and best wishes on your endeavors!  

As always, I welcome any questions you may have regarding our group or your business ventures! 

Stacey Mac, Owner 
Sonas Ventures LLC, which owns and operates: 
Sonas Real Estate, a division of Century 21 Abigail Adams 
Sonas Assistants, Workshops on Executive Assistant Training 
SUP SONAS, Stand Up Paddleboarding, Surfing & Travel in Boston, New England and Costa Rica

http://www.Facebook.com/NewEnglandNetworkforWomen

MEMBER SPEAKER:  

Ted Behr

Topic: "How to Get More Stuff Done by Working Smarter, Not Harder"

Coach Ted Behr works with business owners and other professionals who struggle with procrastination and disorganization who are tired of their difficulties in getting things done.  He supports them in overcoming these challenges so that they can reach their goals and live happier and more fulfilled lives.  He specializes in working with adults with ADD/ADHD.

Through his company Expressway to Success, Coach Ted applies his intelligence, wit and several decades of wisdom to energize and inspire the experienced, intelligent professionals he serves.  He is an Associate Certified Coach through the International Coach Federation and holds a certification as a Professional Co-Active Coach from The Coaches Training Institute as well as specialized training in ADD/ADHD coaching.

results.description:
6:45-7:00 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

7:00 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the ones with our discs out.

Join us as each week as two special Divine beings join us bringing forth great movement, joy, healing and transformation. You will relax in reclining chairs, as the lights are turned down, soft rejuvenating and healing music is played and a special channeled Journey with a team of special Angels, Goddess's Ascended Masters, Saints and Divine Energies join us each week. Dear Kizomba fans,

New intermediate kizomba 8 week program starts this Monday April 25th! You should know the basics already to attend this program, otherwise join our Wednesdays beginners class at 7pm.


SIGN UP in advance and SAVE $20!! OF 8 WEEK PROGAM HERE * online at http://movesandvibes.com/schedule/

If you are brand new to Kizomba then this is the time to get started. if you're not too sure about it then this is the time to find out for yourself. If you've been to a few classes then this is what you've been waiting for. Come find out why everyone is so excited.

- Professionally developed Kizomba instruction program created by world renowned dancer Manuel 'Dr Kizomba' Dos Santos.
- A series of classes that will follow a progression from week 1 till 8, covering the timing, rhythm and accent of the dance
- Exciting features include learning the unique connection, body motion and dips of Kizomba!
- Being a program as opposed to a 'drop in' class we will be able to progress together through the weeks, mastering the feeling and art of Kizomba
- Most of all its going to be filled with fun, excitement, jokes and smiles! lets do this

* Find out more info and buy your pass to the 8 week program online at http://movesandvibes.com/schedule/
* Alternatively, contact Inna Dançarina to pay in person.

This program is only $100 for 8 classes, making it one of the most affordable dance programs anywhere. And you can save $20 on top o that if you sign up in advance!

Its about inclusiveness not exclusiveness, we cant wait to share this beautiful art with you!!

Moves and Vibes team!

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

Android developers get together for informal discussion of mobile technologies. Everyone is welcome, all interests and skill levels. 


Stop by to talk about the mobile industry, debug some Android code, or hang out with other techies and coders. This is Jaho's newest location. It is downtown, not the South End location. Use the Street number please. Jaho has free WiFi along with the coffee and a wine bar. You can bring a laptop and some code. I will have mine!

This is a double meetup brought to you by the Boston GDG and Boston Android.


Be sure buy a bite to eat or a drink to thank our hosts, Jaho.

See you there!

results.description:
Welcome new members!  Please note, RSVPs are required to attend this 35-person, multi-site game night.  The open RSVP spots on Meetup are for new members.


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have about 35 attendees each week, including regulars and new members.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.  If you are having a hard time getting a spot, please send a message to the organizer and we will try to work something out!

2. We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5 towards our site fees.  After that, game night is completely free!

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for when the room is less full -- typically we thin out slightly by 10:00.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  (We do play some light games, but if that's the main thing you want to play, please try our Light Game Night instead!)  Our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right.  We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5.00 that goes towards site fees.

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block away from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza.  We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot).  When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Not as Light Game Night (Monday)

results.description:
Join us for our May book club meetup at Bistro Chi in Quincy Center (37 Cottage Ave.). This month, we'll be discussing Station Eleven by Emily St. John Mandel.

About the book: An audacious, darkly glittering novel set in the eerie days of civilization's collapse, Station Eleven tells the spellbinding story of a Hollywood star, his would-be savior, and a nomadic group of actors roaming the scattered outposts of the Great Lakes region, risking everything for art and humanity.

If you'd like to participate, stop by the circulation desk at the Main branch (40 Washington St.) and ask for a copy of the book; they are held at the desk under the Grownups 20/30s book club account. Or, if you'd prefer an ebook, try checking a copy out here: http://ow.ly/10F8rs. Then, just show up at Bistro Chi at 7 p.m. on May 9, ready to talk about what you liked and didn't like about the book. If you're on Goodreads, friend us (http://www.goodreads.com/thomascranelibrary) to carry the conversation beyond our meetup.

Please, if at all possible, BRING CASH to our meetup if you'd like to order food and drink. Thanks!
results.name: Fine Liquorature Book Club: May Meetup

results.description:
Join us for a guided meditation to help you achieve a state of well-being, relaxation, and strengthen your connection to self. 

Each week, Elaine & Nicol alternate leading the group in a guided meditation to induce a deepened state of relaxation, healing on all levels.  You can achieve an expanded state of self and a higher state of consciousness, connecting you to the ALL that IS! 

Elaine and Nicol are able to connect with the most highest vibrations and frequencies of light that serves the group as a whole.  Your personal experience will be enhanced by the group setting. 

All levels of meditators are welcome to join us.  A sacred space is created to help you feel safe and comfortable. 

Please RSVP your intention on attending.  Cost is $5 at the door.  Doors open at 6:45pm with the group staring at 7pm! 

Visit our website for more info www.essencehealing.net
results.name: Weekly Meditation Group

results.description:
Since so many of you are professional creatives, artists and musicians, thought this might be of interest to you. I will be posting another event more specific to Expression and Creativity soon as well. Hope you can join us!  Trish

Do you want to be more compelling in your marketing messages?

Do you want to understand your customer better and help them get more of what they want?

Would you like to identify new markets, trends and “what’s next?”

The marketing world is constantly changing, and with all the online opportunity, it has become more critical than ever that you understand your customer, identify current trends and that you have a compelling message that can cut through all the noise.

Using a new approach called the Four Forces Framework (FFF), learn how to better understand your customers and address what it is they really want.

You will learn:

·  The four desires/forces that are the motivation for everything

·  How to identify your customers “strategy” so that you can help them get what they want

·  How to write powerful copy that speaks to the heart of your customer and creates desire to act

·  How to align your business to get the most leverage and amplification in your marketing and product development

·  How to identify trends and new customers using the FFF

This will be a practical workshop where you will have time to work on your own marketing in small groups. Bring current marketing materials or ideas for a marketing and messages that you would like to work with.

Cost:  Free. We will have an optional contribution basket if you feel like the workshop was valuable and you would like to contribute.

Limited Attendance: Signup early, this is limited to 25 people and is being promoted to 3 groups. 

This training is part of a larger 10 month training program that I charged $5000 for last year.

About Trish
Trish Blain has been a renaissance explorer and social entrepreneur since 1989, having 9 startups of her own. She has had several business on the cutting edge of culture such as an environmental store when compact light bulbs were $38 each, and a holistic health expo before yoga was popular. In addition she has been a business consultant and coach since 2005. She has turned around and helped to revitalize several companies that were going out of business and has offered thousands of hours of consulting, mentoring and personal development for startups and small businesses that want to amplify their passion. A background as an artist, she adds branding, graphic design and website design for a full service approach with her clients.

Her latest social mission business is The Ollin Institute, which supports living “all-in” and our collective and individual evolution. The institute has at his foundation an approach that she has developed over 20 years called The Four Forces Framework.

Testimonials about Trish’s Consulting Work:

“Trish provides valuable consultative services. She is a talented facilitator and is so much more than a meetup leader. You usually find this format in professional workshops and seminars with a huge price tag. ”

“Trish has a genius for bringing out the genius in others.”

“Trish is often ahead of her time…It took me about a year to see that she was right on target.  Working with her has helped me to see the world in a new way that has brought me unexpected business.”

“Through working with Trish, I have a whole new perspective on what my companies [sic] future looks like. I went from worried about the future, to excited about all the opportunities.”

“Compared to the many who I’ve met -- I think that Trish is an outstanding individual.  She is creative, innovative, and charismatic.  She is a great asset to any organization that she works with.”

“Trish has assisted me as a marketing consultant.  She is an artful questioner and listener.  Using these skills, she has helped me see myself in a new light.  I feel clearer about my strengths and more confident in my abilities.  As a result of our work together, I have a better appreciation of my areas of expertise and have developed new topics for presentations.  Trish is also savvy about the Internet and is currently helping me develop my online presence."

Using a new approach called the Four Forces Framework (FFF), learn how to better understand your customers and address what it is they really want.

You will learn:

·  The four desires/forces that are the motivation for everything

·  How to identify your customers “strategy” so that you can help them get what they want

·  How to write powerful copy that speaks to the heart of your customer and creates desire to act

·  How to align your business to get the most leverage and amplification in your marketing and product development

·  How to identify trends and new customers using the FFF

This will be a practical workshop where you will have time to work on your own marketing in small groups. Bring current marketing materials or ideas for a marketing and messages that you would like to work with.

Cost:  Free. We will have an optional contribution basket if you feel like you would like to support the work and the meetup group.

Limited Attendance: Signup early, this is limited to 25 people and is being promoted to 3 groups. 

This training is part of a larger 10 month training program that I charged $5000 for last year.

About Trish
Trish Blain has been a renaissance explorer and social entrepreneur since 1989, having 9 startups of her own. She has had several business on the cutting edge of culture such as an environmental store when compact light bulbs were $38 each, and a holistic health expo before yoga was popular. In addition she has been a business consultant and coach since 2005. She has turned around and helped to revitalize several companies that were going out of business and has offered thousands of hours of consulting, mentoring and personal development for startups and small businesses that want to amplify their passion. A background as an artist, she adds branding, graphic design and website design for a full service approach with her clients.

Her latest social mission business is The Ollin Institute, which supports living “all-in” and our collective and individual evolution. The institute has at his foundation an approach that she has developed over 20 years called The Four Forces Framework.

Testimonials about Trish’s Consulting Work:

“Trish provides valuable consultative services. She is a talented facilitator and is so much more than a meetup leader. You usually find this format in professional workshops and seminars with a huge price tag. ”

“Trish has a genius for bringing out the genius in others.”

“Trish is often ahead of her time…It took me about a year to see that she was right on target.  Working with her has helped me to see the world in a new way that has brought me unexpected business.”

“Through working with Trish, I have a whole new perspective on what my companies [sic] future looks like. I went from worried about the future, to excited about all the opportunities.”

“Compared to the many who I’ve met -- I think that Trish is an outstanding individual.  She is creative, innovative, and charismatic.  She is a great asset to any organization that she works with.”

“Trish has assisted me as a marketing consultant.  She is an artful questioner and listener.  Using these skills, she has helped me see myself in a new light.  I feel clearer about my strengths and more confident in my abilities.  As a result of our work together, I have a better appreciation of my areas of expertise and have developed new topics for presentations.  Trish is also savvy about the Internet and is currently helping me develop my online presence."

results.description:
Our lighter games meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, a few buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 11:00.  There are two excellent cafes right there, Clover and Bailey & Sage. Their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, The Resistance: Avalon, Bang! The Dice Game, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Saboteur, 6 Nimmt!, Hanabi, No Thanks!, Incan Gold, Forbidden Island

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Not as Light Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Face the street and walk one building to your right.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) Walk back to Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) Walk back to Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.
results.how_to_find_us: Steps from the Kendall Square Red Line, in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

results.description:
Three PyCon-bound speakers will rehearse their talks, sponsored by American Well.


Dan Riti: Remote Calls != Local Calls: Graceful Degradation when Services Fail

In a world where we are becoming more dependent on the network to be reliable due to trends to decouple systems into distributed services, we must do our best to expect failure to occur everywhere and anywhere. This talks aims to explore different techniques for gracefully degrading when the networks fail and the services we depend on are no longer available.  More info...

Matt Bachmann: Better Testing With Less Code: Property Based Testing With Python

Standard unit tests have developers test specific inputs and outputs. This works, but often what breaks code are the cases we did not think about. Property based testing has developers define properties of output and has the computer explore the possible inputs to verify these properties. This talk will introduce property based testing and provide real world examples and patterns.  More info...

Pizza will be provided.

Because these are rehearsals, we will not be recording.  You'll be able to see the recording from the actual presentation given at PyCon.
results.name: PyCon Rehearsals 3: Graceful Degradation, and Property Testing

Although clearing the mind is an important component of meditation, it is not what Buddha taught to be the final aim.  Buddhist meditation offers an opportunity to expand the capacity of our mind to grow and maintain beautiful and positive attitudes that will imbue all aspects our life.  If we can practice cultivating minds of patient acceptance, love, compassion and wisdom through meditation, this will give us healthy internal ways to respond to everything we encounter through our day. Through introducing special and profound ways of thinking into our meditation, our meditation takes on new life and purpose and is easily incorporated into all of our daily activities outside of our formal meditation time.

Q & A:


Q.  I have never played x-wing, can I still play? 


A.  Yes, we will teach and supply ships and materials.  

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game instead of X-Wing, can we do that? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want.  The game room will accomodate more players doing other games.  Just make sure you have game partners for that game or that you are fine in joining the x-wing game if no other players show up for the other game.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait a few minutes for people to show and make introductions, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.  We usually climb until 9-9:30-ish, but if you'd like to secure partner(s) who can come earlier or stay later, feel free to post to the comment section below.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.


For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing (if you are interested in both). For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Basic Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
A weekly gathering bringing together Buddhist meditation practice and recovery. The group will meet weekly in the main practice room to:

~ Meditate with others who are in recovery or exploring recovery

~ Offer contemplations and readings which inspire our recovery and support our practices

~ Share our personal experience, strength and courage

~ Integrate the basic goodness of meditation with our commitment to recovery

'Sobriety is finding a new way of living that involves engagement where there was withdrawal; generosity where there was self-centeredness; community where there was isolation; joy where there was bitterness; trust where there was cynicism.'
  ~ Kevin Griffin, One Breath at a Time: Buddhism and the Twelve Steps

Open to all—meditation practitioners from all traditions and Twelve Step practitioners from all programs.

Leader: John R.  <a>[masked]</a>

Free/suggested donation.

results.description:
Poland: Uncovering the Past and Revealing the Future
with Glenn Kurtz and Leora Tec

The discovery of a three minute home movie from 1938 Poland propels a writer’s search for the family of the filmmaker and the discovery of a lost world. Kurtz embarked on a four-year journey to identify the people in the film and recapture life in the predominantly Jewish town before the Holocaust. His book, Three Minutes in Poland: Discovering a Lost World in a 1938 Family Film was cited as a “Best Book of 2014” by The New Yorker, NPR, and the Boston Globe.

Joining Kurtz will be Leora Tec, director of Bridge to Poland, and organization she founded to share the memorialization of Jewish life being carried out by non-Jewish Poles.

Tickets: $15 + $3 Processing Fee

http://www.jartsboston.org/event/glenn-kurtz-three-minutes-in-poland/


Cosponsored with Hebrew College.
results.name: Poland: Uncovering the Past and Revealing the Future  (Jewish Arts Festival)

Topic: Working with Artists

Have you ever wondered what the best practice considerations are when working with an artist on your game? What exactly their creative process looks like? What pitfalls to look out for when it comes to involving manufacturers? We've invited a Jason Wiser, a wonderful artist, professor and game developer to talk with us on these questions and more.

The format of the talk will be open with plenty of room for questions, so please feel free to leave some in the comments below! Come curious with questions on how to make your game as beautiful as it deserves to be.

New member or old, we're looking forward to seeing you there!

JASON WISER from THE NEW ENGLAND INSTITUTE OF ART

Jason Wiser is the married name of Jason Wiener, Wesleyan University BA grad, Emerson College MFA grad, and former Baltimore Teach For America High School English and Humanities Teacher. He currently teaches Art and Animation at The New England Institute of Art in Brookline, MA, and is Creative Director for Yaya Play Games.

Formerly he was a senior artist/animator for Fire Hose Games in Cambridge, MA on Slam Bolt Scrappers and on the predevelopment team for Harmonix Music System's Dance Central, a web designer for online comic book store NextPlanetOver.com in New York and San Francisco, and a college instructor at the Art Institute of California – San Francisco.

Location Info:

160 Boylston St, Boston, MA 02116


1) You already have the address, but it's right next to the Steinway Piano sign, above the antique shop.

2) Ring the bell for floor four. It is marked "Emerson" on a hand-written tab.

3) Walk to the back and take the elevator to the 4th floor. The elevator is old, slow, and creaky but rest assured it does work.

4) Welcome to the Engagement Game Lab space!

If you have any questions or if you have any trouble getting in, feel free to call or text us at:

Sam:[masked]


Jeff:[masked]

results.description: Monday, May 9, 7:30 PM NEON BULL Studio Cinema, 376 Trapelo Road, Belmont Directed by Gabriel Mascaro 2015 | 101 min. | Brazil, Uruguay, The Netherlands | Portuguese with English subtitles | New England premiere Iremar works the vaquejadas, a traditional sport similar to rodeo from the rural northeast of Brazil and Brazil’s second highest grossing sport after soccer. He and his co-workers live in the truck used to transport the animals, forming a makeshift, but close-knit family. But the country and region are changing and the area’s booming clothing industry has Iremar dreaming of becoming a fashion designer. A wild and sexy ride of a film! Winner at both the Venice Film Festival and Toronto International Film Festival. Contains several graphic sex scenes. Sponsored by the Consulate General of Brazil in Boston. Speaker: Dario Borim, Professor of Portuguese at UMass-Dartmouth, who teaches graduate and undergraduate courses in Luso-Brazilian literature, cinema, theater, and music.
results.name: Film festival features Brazilian film, Neon Bull, in Portuguese

results.description:
LGBT Bullying - Translating Research to Action to Improve the Health of All Youth

More info & presenter bios HERE. Register HERE. This event is free and open to the public. 

May 10th, 8am-4:30pm

Joseph B. Martin Conference Center, Harvard Medical School, Boston

: :: ::

Overview: This symposium will bring together researchers, clinicians, community members, city and state representatives, and school leaders to discuss how to advance current research and intervention approaches with the goal of improving understanding of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) bullying and its effects on child and adolescent health. This dynamic program will enhance dissemination of new information, foster new cross-disciplinary collaborations, and catalyze development of innovative, evidence-based interventions and policies to decrease bullying, increase resilience, and improve health for all youth. Join the dialogue to address health disparities in sexual and gender minority youth!

:: :: ::

Agenda

8:00am-8:30am - Registration and Breakfast

8:30am-8:40am – Welcome - Mark Schuster, MD, PhD, Boston Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School

8:40am-9:30am - Keynote Address - Nicole Maines of Becoming Nicole by Amy Ellis Nutt

9:30am-11:00am - Stigma-based Bullying

• Jaana Juvonen, PhD, University of California Los Angeles

• Wayne Maines, EdD, (father to Nicole Maines)

• Rebecca Puhl, PhD, University of Connecticut, Rudd Center for Food Policy & Obesity

• David Williams, PhD, MPH, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Harvard University

• Michelle Williams, ScD, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health (moderator)

11:00am-11:15am - Coffee Break

11:15am-12:45pm - LGBT Bullying & Discrimination

• S. Bryn Austin, ScD, Boston Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health (moderator)

• Cameron Hardie, Boston Latin Academy

• Mark Hatzenbuehler, PhD, Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health

• Ilan Meyer, PhD, University of California Los Angeles

• Sari Reisner, ScD, Boston Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

• ViQuan Smith, True Colors

12:45pm-2:00pm - Lunch and Breakout Sessions

2:00pm-2:30pm - Report Back from Breakout Sessions

• Jeff Perrotti, MA, CAS, Massachusetts Safe Schools Program for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer and Questioning (LGBTQ) Students (moderator)

2:30pm-4:00pm – Interventions

• Gary Bailey, DHL, MSW, ACSW, Simmons College Graduate School of Social Work, Simmons School of Nursing and Health Sciences (moderator)

• Valerie Earnshaw, PhD, Boston Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School

• Dorothy Espelage, PhD, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign

• Sara Forman, MD, Boston Children's Hospital

• Polly Gipson, PhD, University of Michigan

• Amalio Nieves, MS, Boston Public Schools

• Paul Poteat, PhD, Boston College

4:00pm-4:30pm - Closing Remarks - Eliza Byard, PhD, GLSEN

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Join ComNetworkBoston for a networking reception and discussion.

Just a year ago, one of the hottest topics in Greater Boston was the city’s bid to host the 2024 Olympic Games. No matter where one came out on the question of whether or not the Olympics were a good idea for the Hub, from a communications perspective, as the broader narrative evolved from inevitable to untenable, it became a rare and fascinating study in how a public conversation can play out, and the communications strategies that did (and didn’t) make a dent in public opinion. In a recent interview with the Communications Network “Down Comes Goliath: The Outsized Impact of No Boston Olympics”, Chris Dempsey, of No Boston Olympics, shared some reflections about what ultimately made the difference. Now, we are excited to invite you to a special event to deepen that conversation - with Chris and several others closely involved in advocacy and/or sense-making about Boston’s Olympic prospects – and to network with other communications professionals focused on social change.

Panelists: Chris Dempsey of No Boston Olympics, Robin Jacks of NoBoston2024, Steve Koczela of MassINC Polling, and Eric Reddy of the Boston 2024 Organizing Committee 

Moderator: Lauren Dezenski of Politico (formerly Dorchester Reporter)

RSVP via Eventbrite here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/communications-lessons-from-bostons-olympic-bid-tickets-24270366319?aff=ehomecard
results.name: Communications Lessons from Boston’s Olympic Bid

results.description:
How Much Is One American Worth? Public Opinion Toward Globalization

Diana C. Mutz gives the 2015–16 Kim and Judy Davis Dean's Lecture in the Social Sciences at The Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University.

This event is free and open to the public. More info & Registration HERE.  

Tuesday, May 10th, 2016, 4:15pm

Knafel Center, 10 Garden Street, Cambridge

Diana C. Mutz is the Samuel A. Stouffer Professor of Communication and Political Science at the Annenberg School for Communication and in the Department of Political Science at the University of Pennsylvania

:: :: ::

Economic globalization remains extremely controversial in the United States and elsewhere. Nonetheless, opinions do not fall along recognizable partisan lines. In her current research, Professor Diana C. Mutz uses surveys and experimental designs to explore the psychological, political, economic, and philosophical underpinnings of American attitudes toward policies such as international trade and outsourcing. 

Mutz finds that the mass public’s views of international trade are strikingly different from those of economists. Surprisingly, the public’s views have little to do with the impact of trade on their personal economic well-being, let alone economists’ views of trade’s impact on the public. Instead, trade attitudes have more to do with attitudes toward the value of cooperation versus competition and on general attitudes toward citizens of other countries. This evidence highlights Americans’ differential valuation of human lives.
results.name: How Much Is One American Worth?

He is a writer and advocate for religious freedom and the Middle East community manager for the human rights crowdsourcing platform movements.org.

This event is hosted by the Secular Society of MIT.

results.description:
This meeting is sponsored by AKAMAI


Java and CMS: An Open Source Implementation and Lab

These days Content Management Systems (CMS) are becoming the essential part of both enterprise and web content management applications/systems. There are numerous benefits of using a CMS solution based on open standards and technologies rather than re-inventing a solution by every project that deals with content. With the advent of  Java Content Repository (JCR) specs, there are several Java based CMS both Open and Closed Source projects/products offer varieties of implementation based on JCR. Hippo CMS is a well evolved Open Source CMS technology which uses Apache Jackrabbit Implementation of JCR. 
This session is about:A Quick overview of JCR (JSR 170) specs and Apache Jackrabbit ImplementationHippo CMS Introduction and Hands-on Lab (Develop a reusable business component with web presentation logic.) 
Links: JCR 1.0 Specs : http://www.day.com/specs/jcr/1.0/index.htmlApache Jackrabbit: https://jackrabbit.apache.org/jcr/index.htmlHippo CMS Getting Started: http://www.onehippo.org/trails/getting-started/hippo-essentials-getting-started.html

SPEAKER

Mahesh Acharya is a full stack software developer with about 20 years of experience software applications, api and systems development in java and other technologies especially in the area of front-end applications and tools development and operations process automation. Mahesh is currently working as a solution architect at Hippo USA Inc., in Boston, is a strong believer of continuous learning, sharing the knowledge and mentoring others, he is also an active member of NEJUG production team.  LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/mahesh-acharya-863a5025
results.name: Java and CMS: An Open Source Implementation and Lab

HOW TO GET THERE

Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. results.description:
Join us for a presentation by Tom Vollaro, Senior Product Manager at Autodesk on FormIt 360, Autodesk’s new product for conceptual BIM. On the surface, FormIt 360 can be compared to a competitive product like SketchUp or Rhino. However, there is way more to the story. FormIt 360 runs on multiple platforms (iOS, Android, Web and Windows), allows for integrated analysis, and has a clean back and forth interoperability with Revit. In this presentation, we will cover these aspects and much more, including how FormIt can be used as a general purpose modeler for construction and other workflows besides architectural concept design.

We'll also have a presentation by Zachary Kron on Dynamo. Dynamo is a general purpose graphical algorithm editor that helps designers, architects, artists, and engineers visually script behavior.  Dynamo is both a standalone design environment and a parametric extension to other applications such as  Autodesk Revit and FormIt.  Dynamo users can create geometric systems, analyze existing projects, and turn data into built forms.

Please bring ideas for topics for discussion or demonstration that you'd like to see covered at an upcoming meeting.

Please RSVP if you'd like to attend. Autodesk has been kind enough to provide pizza, salad and beverages for those in attendance.
results.name: May 2016 Meetup Featuring FormIt 360 and Dynamo

results.description:
The world of sales development has exploded in the past few years.  Some may say that it is the new hotness in sales.  But with anything that is new, how exactly does one go about starting an sales development team, what are the best practices, is there a guide to help sort it all out?

In this session, we are honored to have Trish Bertuzzi of The Bridge Group to join us for a discussion about sales development.  We will talk about the lessons she learned about inside sales / sales development and dive into some of those insights she shared in her excellent book The Sales Development Playbook.  

Come join us for an opportunity to here from the most important thought leaders in the sales space.  As a bonus, we everyone that signs up and attends the event receives a free copy of Trish's book.  We look forward to seeing you tomorrow and please do share with your friends and colleagues in sales as well as over http://entsale.co/trishbertuzzi">LinkedIn and Twitter­.


******* 


About Our Speaker

Novelist Jonathan Franzen said, "One-half of a passion is obsession, the other half is love." With that in mind, ask anyone who's met Trish and they'll tell you - she is passionate about inside sales.

Trish often remarks how lucky she is to work with an amazing team at The Bridge Group, helping sales and marketing leaders make the big decisions: on implementation strategy, performance improvement process, supporting technology, and metrics and measurement.

Over the last two decades, Trish has promoted inside sales as a community, profession, and engine for revenue growth. In the process, The Bridge Group has worked with over 200 B2B technology clients to build, expand, and optimize their inside sales efforts.

Through a combination of hard work and timing, Trish and her team's research and ideas have been featured on Inc.com, in Forbes, by associations like SLMA and AA-ISP, and across more than 68 sites in the sales and marketing world.

*******


About Our Sponsors

• If you want great in-product experiences without writing code, visit Appcues


• If you are looking for a kickass mobile sales assistant app, download Spiro

• If you are seeking your next sales gig, set up your candidate profile on Hired

• If you want to extend your social selling reach, we recommend GrowthChamp


• If you need to increase the performance of your sales reps, talk to Selleration

• If you are running events and need better check-in software, Boomset is great

• If you need a live video platform for your events,  Livestream is your best bet

If you would like to learn more about being a sponsor, please reach out to Mark Birch at [masked] for more information.
results.name: The Sales Development Playbook w/ Trish Bertuzzi

Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4

Are you new to paddling? No problem! We'll show you everything you need to know to paddle on a dragon boat. This is a great way to meet people, get in shape, and do something fun in the sun.

results.description:
Walkers & Joggers Welcome

May 3, 2016 @ 6:15PM (every Tuesday and Thursday night for 9 wks)

We're here to help you achieve your goal of beginning to run your first 5K. Too many people have been turned off of running simply by trying to start off too fast. Their bodies rebel, and they wind up miserable, wondering why anyone would possibly want to run in the first place. You should ease into your 5K training plan gradually. In fact, the beginners' program we outline here is less of a running regimen than a walking and jogging program. The idea is to transform you from couch potato to runner, getting you to begin running a 5K or 3.1 miles and on a regular basis in just two months.  Each session should take about 20 or 30 minutes, three times a week. That just happens to be the same amount of moderate exercise recommended by numerous studies for optimum fitness. This program will get you fit. 

We will be meeting twice a week, so you SHOULD train the 3rd time on your own either on Saturday or Sunday to keep with the schedule.  Remember to bring your sneakers and some water.
  http://www.coolrunning.com/engine/2/2_3/181.shtml


Inclement Weather: Heavy rains will cancel. We will train if it is overcast or there is a slight drizzle. Please plan to bring a lightweight jacket with a hood just in case.

results.name: Couch to 5K Training! (Walkers & Joggers Welcome!)

results.description:
We're back at ExtensionEngine this month. Thanks to our UX expert Jess for hosting this event! =)


The doors are security token access only after 6pm. When you arrive, call or text Nicole at[masked] and we'll let you in. The main door is surrounded by a few logos including ExtensionEngine (don't enter via the Citizen Bank entrance). Once you are inside, take the elevator down to the basement. Once you depart the elevator, walk straight and you'll see a glass conference room titled, "Yoda" and that's where we'll be! There will be posters to help clarify the location.

Bring your laptop, current project(s), and prepare to make some progress! Folks have walked away grinning from our previous project nights after solving problems that had been frustrating them for a while. We'll do introductions around 6:45pm to get a sense of the skill set in the room, then settle in to work.

These sessions are super-informal and low-key. We always have attendees of all experience levels--don't feel like you have to be "good" or know "something" before you can come hang out with us. If you feel like the term pre-beginner applies to you, project nights are a great time to meet other code-curious women and start figuring out what you need to learn to start working toward your goals. We guarantee that you'll meet someone who will nerd out about what you are interested in and make you excited to start tinkering.

On hand to help out will be:

Jessica Pang is an Interactive Designer at ExtensionEngine, an online education software development company. She has spent the past 4 years there working on projects from the ground up. Jessica has experience in wire framing, branding, user experience design, and user interface design.

Sahidya Devadoss is the Lead Application Developer at Rapid7. In her everyday work she develops products that help organizations establish a digital footprint. She is a cross functional software engineer with expertise in creating effective web & mobile products.


Kathleen Csizmadiais a graduate of the General Assembly Web Development Immersive program. She is a contributor for Code For Boston, a volunteer civic innovation organization created by Boston-area developers, designers, urban planners, data geeks, and researchers. She works with PostgreSQL, Ruby, Ruby on Rails, Javascript, and CSS.

Reasons why you should come work with us:

Accountability: it's the perfect way to get away from it all (other work, family/housemates, the laundry) and work.

Nerd friends: you'll meet other women who are coding and creating awesome stuff.

Practice: it's an opportunity to practice some of the skills you've picked up if you've taken some of our classes.

Brain exchange: you can ask your neighbor for help on a bug or teach a n00b how to do something you've mastered.

No agenda: Have non-technical work to do? Need a sounding board? Looking for feedback? Just want to get your inbox under control? You're welcome too!

Perks:

+ Fast, reliable internet

+ Way more fun than working in a coffee shop =)


Location

ExtensionEngine

196 Broadway


Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall / MIT

You will need to fill out the rock gym waivers and TAKE their Belay test, if you haven't already.

Day Passes
- $20 Adult*
- $16 Student/Military
* There are also punch-cards available to get 10 Day-Passes for the price of 9 visits

Gear Rental
- $8 Full Package
- $5 Harness
- $5 Shoes
- $2 Chalk
- $2 Belay Device

Membership options and further details are available on the website. You can also fill out a waiver online to save on paperwork when you arrive at the gym.

results.description:
We're a group of friendly folks who just love playing and getting together on a regular basis.  Our skills range from advanced beginner through experienced, and we're happy to help a 'newbie' or two learn the game.  Please bring a set if you have one; everyone will also need their own mah jong card.  Note that we will be playing American-style Mah jong, which is slightly different from Chinese mah jong.  American-style requires a mah jong card and uses jokers.  

We'd like to start the games at 6:30 promptly; feel free to come early and grab a bite from the Wegmans' cafe.  I'm typically upstairs around 6:00 to eat, meet, and greet!

Hope to see you on Tuesday nights!

--Jill
