results.description:
What does it mean to be a man? Have you ever taken some time to ponder that?

Are you living your own definition of being a man or someone else’s? Do you sometimes wonder if you are a “real” man or what that term even means?

Too many men say they don’t have a place or a friend to talk to about what is really important to them; their goals, their fears… whatever it might be. For Friday the 13th, come out and explore the fears and superstitions of being a man.

(RSVP here, but please also go to NavitasCoach.com/men to pay for this event.)


-------------------------------------------------------------------- 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eMsUK0FTWYY

-------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Who Should Come?

Do you long for a community of men that centers around more than beer, sports, or putting people down? If you are open and willing to explore what being a man means to you, this interactive workshop, To Be A Man, is for you.

What Will You Receive?

You will leave with a greater awareness of the "rules" for being a man you've lived under, and the freedom to make your own definition.


Attendees will also have input on the date and time for a new monthly men's group.

How Will We Proceed?

We will use group shares, an exploration of pop culture, and guided meditations to explore your definition of being a man and help you decide if it serves you or hinders you.

Questions to Think About

1) What does being a man mean to me? 
2) What is a "real" man?

Our Presenter: Andy Grant

Andy Grant is the founder of Real Men Feel, and is a best-selling author, award-winning speaker, transformational energy coach, Akashic Records reader and suicide prevention activist. He holds certificates in positive psychology, the Enwaken Coaching System, Akashic Records, and Reiki, as well as other leadership programs and energy work modalities. 

Andy hosts a live weekly Blab, called Reel Men Feel and facilitates a monthly men's group at Circles of Wisdom in Andover, MA

Real Men Feel is a movement where men are allowed to share and to feel whatever is going on for them. You define what it means to be a man. When you authentically live your definition and enjoy your life, you've got a winner.

Testimonials

"What a great class! Tackled the tough topics…Andy has a way of simplifying things and motivating his audience. I applaud his “guts” for getting a group of men together, taking on such topics, and helping us feel more hu- man."
~ David Wahl
results.name: Real Men Feel: To Be A Man (an interactive workshop)

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:


Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (Southeastern Hiking Club)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor:
Wendel C.

Sponsored by:
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location:
Abington/Weymouth Town Line, Rt 18, see exact address above

Cost:
$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.


Attendance Limit:
15 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of high thick socks, similar to those you would wear with roller blades or ski boots (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-7 or Mens 3-6
Medium - Womens[masked] Mens[masked]
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP:
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- We meet in the Zass Zumba Studio, look for the yellow sign in the strip mall

- Don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- Don't eat a full meal (or drink too much) up to an hour before class.

- Open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, it may run a few minutes past the hour, it's ok to go inside and wait.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 

Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.
results.name: Kangoo Jumps Workout

results.description:
Please note the date change, which I have made so as not to conflict with other Social Philosophizer meetups on May 5 and 6.

Are people qualified to run their own lives, or should they defer to trained philosophers? The question is not as ridiculous as it seems. When Plato appears at Google headquarters, he makes a strong case that just as you trust the straightening of your teeth to an orthodontist, it makes sense to trust the straightening of your path to a philosopher. But no sooner does Plato convince us, than a Google employee and Plato's book-tour manager (neither one a philosopher) make compelling cases for other views. Their Socratic debate is a literary and philosophical tour de force that you will not soon forget.

To set it up, author Rebecca Goldstein provides a chapter of scholarly background, which we will also discuss. She touches on everything from the philosophy of science to Plato's Sublime Braid of truth, beauty and goodness.

Please come prepared, having read chapters Alpha and Beta of the book. And stay tuned to the discussion page on this website for a head-start on some of the questions we'll consider! Also feel free to start additional discussions there.

**************************************** 

ADMISSION FEE:

Bronze and Gold Members are admitted free.


If you are not  a Bronze or Gold Member (paid members), there are two ways by which you may attend:


1) Become a Bronze Member ($15 per year): you will find the payment link on the Membership Page.

2) Message Arthur (Organizer) by clicking the message link on his PROFILE. This applies both for cases in which you are not a paid member but want to attend, or if you are a Bronze or Gold member but would like to bring a guest. Payment  of admission for a single meeting can be arranged.


PLEASE FOLLOW THE ABOVE INSTRUCTIONS. AND DO NOT REGISTER ANY RSVP--YES OR NO--UNLESS YOU ARE A BRONZE OR GOLD MEMBER). RSVP and No-Show Policy (please read).


****************************************


BRONZE MEMBERSHIP  entitles you to attend great events such as study group meetings, Impromptu Philosophizers, and more! Instead of paying the admission fee for this event, you can purchase a Bronze Membership for only $15 for a full year's membership. To purchase a Bronze Membership, please visit the Membership Page .
results.name: Plato at the Googleplex Study Group: Chapters Alpha and Beta (BRONZE)

results.description:
• THE BOSTON DRUM CIRCLE

• A high-energy, FUN, celebration of drumming and community. For beginners who want to try something new, their friends, experienced drummers, dancers beginners to experts. NO EXPERIENCE REQUIRED!

• We celebrate the traditions - rhythms that have built energy for hundreds of years for celebration, dance, ritual - just plain FUN! As well as whatever you bring to it!

The cost is $10.00 and many people like to pay before coming. if so, you may use PayPal Here: https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=D828CV9K4JFV8

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

results.description:
PLEASE DO NOT DOUBLE RSVP! ----PLEASE RSVP IN ONE GROUP ONLY!! 

Join the legendary crazy dancing at our Mix +Mingle Meetup Private Party for 120+ members with our own DJ, dance area, 2 bars +apps/food from 7-9PM.

7-9PM is the Social Mixer which the best because it allows you to get to know your fellow Meetup members. After 9PM the crazy dancing + loud music starts so please do not complain, since members come to dance to loud music after 9PM.

Bonus FREE KARAOKE on 1st  floor if you want to kick it KARAOKE style.

Its the party everyone loves since its he starting point for thousands of new friendships, real long term relationships and 57+ marriages. Remember this is not a Singles Party it's a Social party.

results.description:
In this workshop, we will cover the basic components of a subtractive synthesizer: Oscillators, Filters, Envelopes, and LFOS. The discussion will include both the technical aspects of synthesis and signal flow as well as the practical applications of using each component to shape a sound. We will also explore how subtractive synthesis concepts can apply to other forms of synthesis such as FM and Wavetable.

Working as a freelance producer/engineer and club DJ, Jason has built a career in the audio world both in the studio and on the stage. After graduating from Berklee in 2004, Jason began his career working in studios in and around Boston producing and engineering records for a variety of bands, artists, and rappers. In 2005, Jason became one half of the DJ duo Jefr Tale. As part of Jefr Tale, Jason hosted a weekly radio show on SiruisXM, performed at some of the biggest festivals and venues across the North America and Brazil (including Ultra Music Festival, Red Rocks Colorado, and Burning Man), and produced a string of successful original releases. Following up on the success of Jefr Tale, Jason plunged deeper into electronic production, working with several other DJ and producers and branching out into hip hop production and pop songwriting. Jason continues to split his time evenly between producing, engineering, writing, and performing.

RSVP and reserve a spot here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/synthesis-building-blocks-513-free-tickets-25358731649
results.name: Synthesis Building Blocks [5/13] #FREE

results.description:
Hello Astros fans,

Let's take this party on the road!  Join me as we take the Gulf Coast to the East Coast when the Astros travel to Boston to take on the Red Sox.   We will be in the heart of Red Sox Nation, pilgrams in a foreign land!

Details will be worked out in the coming weeks.  But, I plan to travel as a group, stay in a nearby hotel, and all wear our Astros Colors in Fenway.  I want to order our tix by the end of the week.  A friend is searching hotels and air fair. I only have three others confirmed, so a total of four. 

This will be my first real visit to Boston, so I'd like to fly in Thursday night May 12th, and return Monday morning May 16th.  We will have Friday afternoon, Saturday Afternoon, and all day Sunday to be tourists.  We will probably stay outside of Boston, and take the rail into town and Fenway. 

This is also graduation time in Boston, so rooms will be scarce.  I want to get seats somewhere behind home plate (or, as close to it as possible), and somewhere along the first base line. 

Please send $175 via PayPal using my email address; [masked]  Please select the "Send Money to Friends and Family" option in order to avoid service charges.  I'm sorry, but I will not be responsible for service fees.  Please feel free to contact me with any questions, sooner rather than later ;-)

Ticket purchase must be paid in full by January 29th. 

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions. 

Let's go Astros!
results.how_to_find_us: We will travel as a group.  Feel free to test or call 713-503-1933
results.name: Astros Trip to Fenway Park, Thur May 12 thru Mon May16

results.description: Location: MIT Stata Center (Building 32), Room 141, 32 Vassar Street, Cambridge. Dora is a garment designer and crocheter; she’ll tell us about all the textiles she’s seen traveling around the world. As always, come by for a free stitch session before the meeting. Admission for guild members is always free, guests are $6.00 at the door. See you there!

results.description:
Tee up and drive on over to the Social Restaurant in Newton to join us from 7:00 to 9:30 for our season opening social event!!  Meet new members, reconnect with others, enjoy a great assortment of appetizers, flat breads, and other finger foods. Enjoy libations from the cash bar. Hear about Boston Chapter and National news and upcoming events!

We heard you when many of you told us that making it to a dinner event on a Friday evening is hard, so we've arranged for 2-1/2 hours of appetizers so that no one misses the main course!

Stay and dance the night away after the main event!!  The band comes on at 9:30 in the main room and we've arranged for reserved tables.


Cost:  $25 per person. CASH Bar. Please make checks payable to ASGA Boston Chapter and either mail to Mike Lawton, 270 East Street, Apt. 2, East Walpole, MA  02032 OR bring it to an ASGA event by May 1.


Attn NEWCOMERS:    we'll have a drawing for a free one-year ASGA National membership--a $79 value!!!

PARKING IS FREE!!!  Park in the garage attached to the hotel and get your parking ticket validated in the restaurant!
results.how_to_find_us: In the private room between between the main dining room and the hotel lobby.

results.description:
Join us for an evening of fun and connection as we play 3 communication games where we get the opportunity to say the truth and be real with each other (no touching and no one takes off any clothes). It's a great start to your evening!


Imagine meeting new people in an environment where everyone feels comfortable to be themselves. It’s a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation—a place where everyone gets to say the truth and feel heard. Through other people putting quality attention on you, and asking you questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening—really listening—to your responses, you have the opportunity to examine yourself. It’s a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good, which allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

You can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you. You don't have to do anything you don't want to, or answer any questions you don't want to answer. The games are designed to create the sensations in your body that you might have during Orgasmic Meditation* without having to actually do the practice—just through talking. What comes up might surprise you.

Even in a room full of strangers, it's amazing how connected we can end up feeling when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston. 

*At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation, which class or private training you can take with our masterful teachers and coaches, and what we have to offer so you can have more connection, authenticity, and play in your life!

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time—we lock the door promptly at 7:40!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). 

Park at Alewife station for $7. and it's a ten minute walk to the center.

Nicole Daedone (founder of Orgasmic Meditation) on the science of OM:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qg59pToG-Bk&ebc=ANyPxKq5gRnQf_jjWM_RZoCU4BnjyJ3-SMZpf8urZ5SRhyRtOo2yq3hh0SJoMjckytt2C0TE0DkhdufRilud2cfOT8_DxjM_2g
results.how_to_find_us: Corner of Cedar and Dudley Streets

Hey everyone,
I wanted to share with you that one of my favorite social / networking groups, Boston Young Professionals Assoc., is celebrating their 13th anniversary and having an event in May. Every BYPA event Ive been to is always a blast. Please see details below. Please also note that simply RSVping to this event DOESN'T guarantee entry to the event. You must purchase a ticket via the link below. Hope to see you all there.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/bostonypas-13th-anniversary-party-tickets-22672400761

BostonYPA has spent the last 13 years creating a community in Boston for young professionals, and it's time to celebrate!! Our friends at Buffalo Trace Bourbon are so excited for us, they are providing complimentary cocktails for everyone in attendance!

Join us at Storyville in Back Bay for food, cocktails and dancing. What's included in your ticket: Admission, Heavy Appetizers (both stationary and passed, so come hungry), a live DJ to help us celebrate and get dancing, and a professional photographer to give us great photos to remember the night.

Buffalo Trace Bourbon is sponsoring the event, and will be treating every attendee to a complimentary full size cocktail!!

Arrive by 9:30, and stay at Storyville to dance the night away until they close at 2am!


Important:

Buffalo Trace is providing each attendee present between 8pm and 9:15 at least one complimentary cocktail to make our celebration even more special. Per state regulations, the cost of your ticket does not include an alcoholic beverage. You must be 21+ to attend, ID will be requested by door staff. Given the excitement and low ticket fee, we expect to be sold to capacity before the event begins. If not, entry will be $30 cash at the door.

The fabulous, fun-filled event begins with a class from 8:00 to 9:15 and continues with dj'd dancing until 11:30pm music provided by some extraordinary DJs.

Alice Heller leads Nia with a World Twist Come celebrate being in your body with a delicious blend of earthy African dance moves and

Alice Heller blends her love of rhythm, movement and spirit to bring you a multidimensionally accessible movement class. No experience required as her classes are based on the body’s way. She is a Certified Blue Belt Via instructor and an African dance teacher. www.alicehellerdance.com

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11, under 23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out. We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can move in.

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join us for a night of west coast swing. We offer a beginner ("Level 1", meant for those with little/no experience), intermediate ("Level 2", meant for those who have mastered the Left Side Pass, Right Side Pass, and Sugar Push), and advanced ("Level 3", meant for those who have mastered whips, tucks, and fundamental techniques) classs from 8:30-9:30pm. If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-12pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, country and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Second-Friday-of-the-Month West Coast Swing Classes & Social Dance!

results.description:
Come help distribute food at the American Red Cross Food Pantry! Some of us volunteered here back in December and really enjoyed it.

Almost 13,000 families across the Massachusetts Region receive a five-to-seven day supply of nutritionally-balanced groceries from the American Red Cross Boston Food pantries and mobile distributions. We will be preparing bags of perishable food, assisting clients, carrying food bags to cars, etc. The expectation is the ability to lift 25lbs. and stand for 3+ hours. No open-toed shoes, please.

The American Red Cross Food Pantry is served by 3 bus lines: #8, #10, and CT 3.

The closest T stop is Andrew Square Station on the Red Line. The #10 bus runs from Andrew Square to 1010 Mass. Ave. across the street from the food pantry.

For those of you driving, there is some limited parking:
-Procter St. across from the entrance to the pantry
-Corner of Mass Ave. + Procter St

Let me know if there are any questions!
results.name: American Red Cross Food Pantry

results.description:
Registration open to kids ages 8 and up! (with adult participant) May is peak season for migrant songbirds, traveling from their winter range (South America, Central America, Mexico) to our area and beyond. We’ll talk about how to identify birds, where to look for them, and what birds you can expect to see in our region. Under the guidance of Andrea Golden, we’ll survey Wright-Locke Farm and the ponds and woods in the abutting conservation lands (Locke Pond and Whipple Hill). This small area provides a variety of habitats for different birds including ducks, herons, woodpeckers and songbirds. Bring binoculars if you have them, and dress for the weather. No dogs are allowed during the walk.

Tuition fee: $10 per person

Click here to register: https://www.wlfarm.org/get-involved?page=CiviCRM&q=civicrm/event/register&reset=1&id=248

This workshop is hosted by Wright-Locke Farm.
results.name: Spring Bird Watching Walk with Andrea Golden

results.description:
Once you register on Southborough Recreation Sports Meetup you can RSVP to play in all the Meetups you want. The $15 per month fee will be collected when you show up to play and will cover you for that month.

Doubles, Mixed Doubles, Singles matches will be played on outdoor hard-courts. All levels 3.0 and higher welcome. You must be able to serve over-head, volley and rally. New tennis balls for each court will be provided.

Based on play level you indicated in your profile initially you will be matched up with similar level players. Adjustment to level may be done based on actual play. Players participating in a session will be emailed the day before with court assignment. You decide on starting teams on each court.

All guests must also register, RSVP and pay the fee to participate. This will ensure we have a spot for your guest...matched to players of similar skill-level.

1st Session matches are from 8:00-8:50AM and 8:50-9:30AM. 2nd Session matches are from 9:30-10:15AM and 10:15-11:00AM. You must RSVP to both sessions if you wish to play from 8AM to 11AM. Matches are w/Ad scoring. Leading team moves up & splits. Other team moves down & splits.

Occasionally, we will have to play at other locations on days ARHS has events. Organizer will change location on the meetup description.

Rain and/or wet courts may force cancellation which will be communicated via e-mail as early as possible.

All players play at their own risk at all times.

Organizers reserve the right to remove any player from the RSVP list or this social tennis Group or the courts at any time for any reason without advance notice.

results.description:
Carl's Diner............known for it's huge servings.........especially the bacon, is cholesterol heaven!

We will be doing a backroads ride to Oxford MA for lunch at Carl's Diner.  Bring your appetite!

 Don't let the exterior fool you. Inside you'll find an original 1920 s style dining car that has been in this location since World War II. Complete with dark quartersawn oak panels and trim, nostalgia is written all over. The portions are enormous and the food is the home style cooking that you would expect from a local landmark. Clearly the local dining hangout, it comes with a whole cast of characters and the humorous off color banter that ensues. Carl's Diner will give you a lot more to take home with that pound plus doggie bag.

Road Captain:  Deeg

Meeting Location:  Dunkin Donuts Randolph across from the Comfort Inn

Meeting time:  830 am

Kickstands up:  9 am
results.name: Bacon Blast

results.description:
http://makeloveweek.com

Join Robyn Vogel, Dr. Martha Tara Lee (Sexologist from Singapore!) and  14   Sexually Empowered, Inspiring and Courageous Relationship Experts


Click HERE  (it's free!)

https://youtu.be/IofGdwFjJck

Every once in a while I like to do a BIG outreach and spread LOVE as far and wide as I can possibly reach!  This year I invited some of my own teachers that I love and adore  - Sex Geek Reid Mihalko, Barbara Carrellas of Urban Tantra; International Author and Relationship Therapist Tammy Nelson (Getting the Sex You Want and The New Monogamy), Laurie Handlers of Butterly Workshops, Elsbeth Meuth and Freddy Weaver of Tantra Nova,  and many more truly wonderful leaders in love, relationship, intimacy and sex in this not-so-new millennium.  

These people have shared their voices far and wide already -- and are loud and clear about how they are supporting men and women in healing their sexual repression, past traumas, infidelities (whether with others or being out of integrity with yourself) and coming into a FULLY LOVING PLACE with YOURSELF (and your beloveds.)  

It's really fun to do the interviews too!   

Make Love Week begins on May 14th!  We'll have a private Facebook group to connect, ask questions, get coaching and discuss the conversations in the interviews.  


Join me by clicking HERE (this brings you to the beautiful page we created and a place to sign in)


TRANSFORM Your Love Life!

• Learn how these experts healed the past, made peace with the present and are forging new paths of sexual expression, self-love and intimacy.

• Get the tools you need to take real life steps toward authentic sexual expression and deeply loving connections.

• Revolutionize your love life and have great sex, too!

I'm looking forward to focusing on Making Love every day with you!

Love,

Robyn 

Our Featured Experts:

Barbara Carrellas
Laurie Handlers
Freddy Weaver/Elsbeth Mueth
Reid Mihalko
Charlie Glickman
Jessica O'Reilly
Nina Manolson
Serena Anderlini
Lindsay Hagamen
Zahava Griss

Tammy Nelson

results.description:
The Foxboro Jaycees host an annual Spring Fair on the Common in May, this year it will be held Saturday May 14th. Since inception in 2010, this event has grown every year, and in 2015 over 50 local artists, crafters, and vendors filled the Town Common from 9am to 3pm. We expect 2016 will be even bigger!

Products offerings include a wide variety, such as handmade quilts and clothing, woodworking, soaps and other body care products, pet accessories, handbags, candles and scented warmers, hand-crafted jewelry, photographs, painted glass, children’s clothing, games & toys, and so much more! There is also a bouncy house for the kids and raffle items available.

This fundraising event for the Foxboro Jaycees will help fund several community programs they coordinate, such as the Annual Easter Egg Hunt, Caroling on the Common, Holiday Decorations for the Common, Bandstand Repair, Fruit Baskets for the Foxboro Discretionary Fund, Sand for Seniors, and other local causes they support.

If you have any questions regarding the Spring Fair, please contact [masked]

=============================

Vendors…  Many more will be added as the registration forms come in!

MK’s Sports MerchandisePampered Chef – Susi AraujoOrigami Owl – Jeanne DavisThe Pear Stop/Serene Pearls – hand made freshwater pearl & crystal jewelry\Cozy Creation by Selina – light up glass block, light up potpourri vaseKent Farm Scarves – hand painted, hand dyed silk scarves, hand crafted soaps, wire wrapped sea glass earrings

results.description:
Come paddle at one of our practice sessions with Living Root, your 2015 Boston Dragon Boat Festival Grand Champions! We're a social and friendly co-ed team who enjoy the sport of dragon boat paddling.

Are you new to paddling? No problem! We'll show you everything you need to know to paddle on a dragon boat. This is a great way to meet people, get in shape, and do something fun in the sun.

We meet at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station. We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather. Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you don't mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings. We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice. So come join us! Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked].

Additional Location and Parking information can be found here

Check out our website or find us on Facebook!

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)

Grow Native Massachusetts is hosting our second annual Native Plant Sale! Adding native plants to your garden is the best way to support biodiversity in your neighborhood— including bees, butterflies, birds, and much more. We will be selling a wide variety of native plants, including: Perennials · Ferns · Grasses · Shrubs · Trees We source our plants from more than ten nurseries around New England, to bring together a range of species rarely found in one location. Come early for best selection. Sale proceeds support our programs. Ask the Experts: Our experienced landscape professionals will answer your questions and help you find the plants best suited to your landscape needs and conditions. This is a tremendous resource!


Learn more at: http://grownativemass.org/programs/plantsale

results.description:
Offering stunning views of rolling fields; rocky shorelines and tree-lined carriage paths; a hike through the World's End Reservation is something you won't want to miss. Join experts from L.L.Bean's Dedham Retail Store as we take you on a four-and-a-half-mile guided excursion through this beautiful 251-acre preserve.

You'll have the opportunity to view this area's unique wildlife and catch sweeping views of the Boston skyline. Please make sure you wear appropriate hiking clothing; waterproof footwear (if possible) and dress for the weather (layers; no cotton). Please bring a small day pack with extra clothes; snacks; water and any personal medications.

Admission is $6 if you're not a Trustees member. Free if you are. Membership info at www.thetrustees.org

ACTIVITY LEVEL:  Moderate

Ages 8 and up are welcome.

Reserve your spot at www.llbean.com/dedham  (note that the event name says "Autumn Hike at World's End", but it's on the above date)

Note:  This meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer attending. Sign up at llbean.com/dedham

results.description:
Once you register on Southborough Recreation Sports Meetup you can RSVP to play in all the Meetups you want. The $15 per month fee will be collected when you show up to play and will cover you for that month.

Doubles, Mixed Doubles, Singles matches will be played on outdoor hard-courts. All levels 3.0 and higher welcome. You must be able to serve over-head, volley and rally. New tennis balls for each court will be provided.

Based on play level you indicated in your profile initially you will be matched up with similar level players. Adjustment to level may be done based on actual play. Players participating in a session will be emailed the day before with court assignment. You decide on starting teams on each court.

All guests must also register, RSVP and pay the fee to participate. This will ensure we have a spot for your guest...matched to players of similar skill-level.

1st Session matches are from 8:00-8:50AM and 8:50-9:30AM. 2nd Session matches are from 9:30-10:15AM and 10:15-11:00AM. You must RSVP to both sessions if you wish to play from 8AM to 11AM. Matches are w/Ad scoring. Leading team moves up & splits. Other team moves down & splits.

Occasionally, we will have to play at other locations on days ARHS has events. Organizer will change location on the meetup description.

Rain and/or wet courts may force cancellation which will be communicated via e-mail as early as possible.

All players play at their own risk at all times.

Organizers reserve the right to remove any player from the RSVP list or this social tennis Group or the courts at any time for any reason without advance notice.

From 10am-2pm, we will gather at Dana Farber to share information about intersex, transgender, genderqueer, bisexual, pansexual and asexual identities. Even if you have not been speaking for a long time, please feel free to attend. 

Plus, enjoy the opportunity to meet other SpeakOUT members and share experiences from the field. Meet and greet at 9:30 with coffee and donuts/fruit before we begin at 10:00. We'll have a light lunch together as well. Free parking is available at Dana Farber.

Everyone who has attended a SpeakOUT training before can attend this for free. If you are someone interested in SpeakOUT and would like to attend, there is a $10 fee. Contact Ellyn at [masked] with any questions.

results.description:
A great intro session if you want to find ways to conquer your fear. And a great oppy for return guests to practice . 


If weeknights are difficult, take advantage of this Saturday meetup to build confident speaking skills. We'll show you a few secrets to defeat the anxiety we all feel in front of groups, and some tips to connect with your audience. [We'll be meeting on Second Saturdays throughout the summer.


Our Meetups are fast-paced and entertaining. Not intimidating. You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meetups run. [This session will supplement our usual Wed evening meeting, not replace it. Sessions start promptly, so please arrive a bit early.]  Please rsvp.

3rd Floor, Room 097. You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking, there is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present your ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.


NOTE: For those who like to plan ahead, we'll be meeting the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays in May.  We'll hold a Second Saturday session in June, as well.

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

Run Details: Meet up with The Most Informal Running Club Ever at 10:00am for the weekly Saturday Fun Run. We'll split up into groups depending on the turnout for distance and time goals for 4, 6 or 7 mile loops. It's your choice!

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at Eastern Mountain Sports on Commonwealth Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com

We are asking everyone who is interested in attending the hackathon to please fill out an application here. We will notify you when you are accepted into the hackathon. 


You will only receive hackathon materials once you've completed the form.


This hackathon is a free, algorithmic trading hackathon. Quants, data scientists, students, and anyone else interested in quant finance, who would like to put their trading strategies to the test, are welcome to participate.  

Participants will learn how to build a trading algorithm with various data sets and have the chance to submit their final algorithms for a grand prize and winners will be determined using a rigorous, quantitative judging process.

Hackathon 2016 Agenda

10AM – 11AM: Introduction to Quantopian, dataset showcases, and explanation of competition rules.

11AM – 12PM: Hackathon Start. Competitors will be free to ask Quantopian panelist questions.

12:00PM – 12:30PM: Lunch

12:30PM – 5:30PM: Hackathon Afternoon Session. Competitors will be free to ask Quantopian panelists questions.

5:30PM – 5:45PM: Final announcement of 6:00 submission deadline.

6:00PM – 6:30PM: Submission deadline, wrap-up. 

Thank you to our Sponsor PsychSignal

PsychSignal is a provider of real time Trader Mood, data, analytics and indices for financial institutions & investment professionals seeking an edge. Learn more: https://psychsignal.com/.

results.description:
We will meet to play Ultimate Frisbee on Saturday morning from 10-12PM at Kendall Square Field (252 Third Street) in East Cambridge. There is metered parking available on Third Street or free, weekend parking at the Kennedy-Longfellow School parking lot, which is a 5-minute walk from the field. We welcome players of all skill levels!

We ask that our members RSVP for the game so we know we have enough people for a game. We will confirm by Friday night 9PM or earlier whether the game is on or not. By RSVP'ing, you also allow us to alert you of last-minute cancellations (usually weather related).

10:00-10:15 AM - Warm up, stretch, and practice. Overview rules and divide into teams.
10:15 AM - Game starts.
Post-game - Hang out, grab lunch.

Please dress appropriately for a game of competitive Ultimate Frisbee. We recommend that you bring white and dark-colored t-shirts so that we can divide into two teams easily. Bring your own water, and we will provide the discs and cones. Come join us for Ultimate Frisbee and make new friends in the process!
results.name: Ultimate Frisbee

results.description:
Park at 280 Ipswich Road, Topsfield, MA

Easy pace ride, it is the beginning of the season

You should RSVP (sign-up) if you plan on riding with the group

Willowdale is part of a massive network of doubletrack and singletracks plowing into the forests of Wenham and the surrounding towns. It networks together with Bradley Palmer State Forest, Georgetown-Rowley State Forest, and Willowdale itself. The trails themselves are a mix of rolling, smooth, and rooted single and doubletrack that makes FANTASTIC riding. Plenty of climbs and technical challenges can be found, but the real high-point is the well-maintained and marked trails that go for miles with countless singletrack shoot-offs that re-merge onto the double track. One of the best rides in Massachusetts! You could ride here every day for a month and not experience everything.

Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

results.description:
register here to secure your spot:


https://www.eventbrite.com/e/crime-and-punishment-in-early-boston-tickets-25107841229


I won't be able to attend, but I'm posting this anyway because Historic Boston always does such informative tours. Hopefully another assistant organizer will sign up to help connect the Nerd Fun members. - H

A pillory similar to this one was a central feature of early Boston, a town where crime and punishment were seen as essential to maintaining a strong and cohesive Puritan community.

On this tour, you'll learn where Bostonians sited their stocks, whipping post, gaol, and gallows. We'll explore the cultural values implict in public punishment, and put them in historical context. We'll bring the story to life with fascinating examples of early colonial crimes and punishments. 

The Puritan churches and the civil government defined appropriate behavior and took action when rules were broken. On this tour, you will learn about the relationship between the two institutions and the role of laws and courts to apply sanctions ranging from minor shaming to corporal punishments, imprisonment, and death.

We look forward to seeing you soon!

Rose

Rose A. Doherty, President, Partnership of the Historic Bostons

We are an all-volunteer organization committed to public history about 17th- century Bostons.  As always, our tours are free.  We suggest a donation of $5 to defray our expenses.

FAQs

Remember that water is always a good idea.

What are my transport/parking options getting to the event?

Parking in Boston is always difficult.  Public transportation to Park Street is recommended.   Click here for schedules. Walk up the hill toward the State House. 

Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?

Contact us on phbostons @ gmail . com


When Saturday, May 14, 2016 from 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM (EDT) - Add to Calendar
Where Massachusetts State House - Front Steps 24 Beacon Street, Boston, MA 02133 - View Map

Salem Trip Itinerary:

-10:30 am -Meet in front of the Essex St Parking Garage

(we will be carpooling and will meet in front of parking garage off of Essex St) across the street from the Visitors Center. Some people can park and others will be driving- there is very limited parking in Salem)

_______________________________________________________

We will begin with a Trolley Tour Ride to see Historic Salem:

The Salem Trolley is the best way to see Salem and to experience the Witch City’s unique and colorful past.  Since 1982, Salem Trolley has set the standard for sightseeing tours and exceptional transportation north of Boston.
The Salem Trolly provides visitors with a narrated one hour tour and all day shuttle service through beautiful and historic Salem.
Our eight mile ride around the city takes you past the Charter Street Burial Ground, the House of the Seven Gables, Witch Dungeon Museum, Salem Witch Museum, the historic waterfront area and other locations, including Chestnut Street considered to be one of the most beautiful streets in America.
Your professional driver and talented local tour guide will entertain you with factual history and interesting tidbits about Salem. Feel free to get off and on at any of our 13 stops throughout the day and view Salem at your leisure, using our trolley as a convenient shuttle service.


http://www.salemtrolley.com/

Prices are: Adults- $15  Children- $5.00 Under 5 yrs- FREE

The trolley runs from 10:00 am- 5:00 pm

____________________________________________________

results.description:
Meeting at edge of parking lot. I will be wearing a blaze orange baseball cap with a longhorn on it. Please arrive 15 minutes early. We start hiking on time; plan your travel accordingly.


The Hike:


We will be hiking (estimated 2-3 hours, 4-5 miles) at a moderate pace over mixed terrain including gentle hills and uneven rocky terrain with moderate elevation gain. If you join us, you must be flexible on the time. We may be taking detours. This will be an adventure. I have piece together several maps (from the Boy Scouts, towns, and Google Earth) to plan our path. We will be TRYING to find Ford’s Folly, a not well known historical location. This is my first attempt; so I can’t guarantee we will find it.

This map is the best one I can share online. Note, this only covers the first part of the hike, later we will be walking off the map to the west. Hopefully, not off the edge of the earth :-) 

http://www.sudburyvalleytrustees.org/sites/default/files/Nobscot.pdf

</a>

History:

Wayside Inn (in Sudbury) is also known as "Longfellow's Wayside Inn", a name given to the inn to capitalize on the popularity of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's "Tales of a Wayside Inn", a book of poems published in 1863. Longfellow visited the Wayside Inn in 1862, when it was called the "How Tavern". In his book "Tales of a Wayside Inn", Longfellow re-published his poem "Paul Revere's Ride" as "The Landlord's Tale".

Henry Ford was the last private owner of the Wayside Inn. He purchased it in 1923, and he also purchased 3,000 acres of land surrounding the Inn, with the aim of developing it into a historically oriented village and museum. Although his original aims were not accomplished at the Wayside, he did establish the non-profit institution that operates the Inn and associated museum, watermill, and archives today.

Less well known is Ford's attempt to create a reservoir for the Wayside Inn. Across US Rte. 20 and now secluded in a wooded area behind private homes is a 30 ft. high stone dam. Dubbed by the locals as "Ford's Folly" the structure failed to retain water because the feeding brook provided insufficient volume and the ground was too porous for a pond to fill.

After Hike, Food and Drinks:

After the hike, we will gather for food and drinks. 

Conrad’s Restaurant
120 Boston Post Rd, Sudbury, MA

RSVP Responsibility!


Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP (don't wait until the day of the event) if you can't make it.

I am only a volunteer. I will be waiting at the trail starting point, and I will be expecting you. I look forward to meeting you.

* No pets allowed on hike.

* Members only. No guests permitted.

* Members must have a valid photo.

* Adults only.


Gear and Dress:

* Hiking boots suggested.


* Dress appropriately for the weather conditions.


* Non-cotton clothing works best.  


* Bring water, snacks and any personal medicines and gear you may need as well.

FOUL WEATHER CANCELS.

You assume all risk associated with this activity.

Liability Waiver: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.


Directions to Hike:

From the East:

Take Mass Pike to exit 13 Natick Route 30 to Route 9 West. Merge on Rt 9. Follow Rt. 9 and bear right on exit (Rt. 30 West Framingham). At the light, take a right onto Edgell Road. Follow Edgell Road for 3.5 miles. Camp entrance is on the left following the Framingham Animal Hospital on the right.

From the South:

Take Route 495 North to Route 9. Take Route 9 East to the exit for Framingham State College. At the light, take a left onto Edgell Road. Follow Edgell Road for 3.5 miles. Camp entrance is on the left following the Framingham Animal Hospital on the right.

From the West:

Take Mass Pike to exit 12, Route 9 East. Follow Rt. 9 through 3 sets of lights to Framingham State College exit. At the light, take a left onto Edgell Road. Follow Edgell Road for 3.5 miles. Camp entrance is on the left following the Framingham Animal Hospital on the right.

From the North:

Take 495 Exit 24 to Route 20 East. Follow Rt. 20 to Nobscot Road, Sudbury (just past Star Market Plaza on the right before Friendly' s). Follow Nobscot Road approximately 1.5 miles. Camp is on the right at 1 Nobscot Road.

Grab your cameras and join us at our first Boston Outdoor Afro event! We'll stroll through the Arnold Arboretum for about two miles, learning about one of the best lilac collections in North America that hosts more than 175 species imported from all over the world, from Canada to China. 

This is a great opportunity to capture photos of the lovely lilacs away from the festival crowds, but while still in bloom. All levels of photographers welcome - from casual Instagrammers to semi-pros! We'll provide some tips for great shots to get you ready for summer. 

Please wear proper footwear for walking two miles and bring at least 20 ounces of water along with hat/sunglasses for sun protection. We'll walk on mostly paved surfaces, but there is some grass and gravel on the paths. There are hills; we will maintain a very casual pace appropriate for all ages and fitness levels. We'll meet drizzle or shine. 

There's free, street parking on both Centre St. and the Arborway; carpooling is recommended. Also a short walk from Forest Hills on the T, or a great destination for biking. 

Please print and bring a completed waiver if you can. Looking forward to a picture perfect event!

results.description:
Love to Garden?  Container gardening makes it all so flexible and versatile, and love that its not so much bending over ;o)  At this luncheon you will learn the proper techniques for container gardening, what plans grow well together and complement each other.    

As some of you might.... or might not know our member Karen McBain is a very talented and budget conscious Garden Designer.  She has been in her own business "Garden Paths Garden Creations " making gardens bloom and look beautiful in Cape Ann Gloucester and surrounding North shore towns for several years.  I personally know her work ethic and she's so great at what she does, and I'm anxious to learn her tips...and watch her at work.  


 Garden Paths Website

She offered to do a special potting class just for our group at her home outside in her pretty garden.   She is sweet and so very gracious to provide the flowers, soil and her expertise showing us great potting ideas for annuals and perennials.     Not sure what flowers work well together? some like shade , some like full sun...who IS to know .. I always get confused.. but Karen knows ;o)  Color, blooming time, drainage needs, and good fillers for your container are questions she'll answer for us and More!  February is almost over and I'm  looking forward to redoing my container pots for this year , are YOU? 


PICNIC LUNCH:  We will also be bringing a sandwich wrap party platter perfect for a picnic lunch.  Ice Tea and Dessert (of minimal calories) will be determined.  Maybe a nice fruit salad?

What to bring to Karen's home?   A small gardening shovel, garden gloves if you don't want to get your pretty nails dirty, and your GARDEN PLANTER, of medium size.  Nothing bigger than 12 inches in diameter so its nice and full.  Plus the bigger it is the "heavier" it is remember, with everything inside. Bring a hat and sunscreen in case its really sunny (so we hope) . Karen will be getting our flowers through her company sources so we will be saving money for sure!

Cost for your lunch and the flowers and soil for your container garden is $30.00 /per person

Thank you Karen!
results.name: Make a pretty Container Garden and Picnic

results.description:
THE DATE: Saturday May 14, 2016 from 12:00-1:30 pm

THE RESTAURANT: Masala Art at 990 Great Plain Avenue , Needham, MA

THE BOOK: Climbing the Mango Trees: A Memoir of a Childhood in India  by Madhur Jaffrey

There are 33+ copies in the Minuteman Library System.

Whether acclaimed food writer Madhur Jaffrey was climbing the mango trees in her grandparents' orchard in Delhi or picnicking in the Himalayan foothills on meatballs stuffed with raisins and mint, tucked into freshly baked spiced pooris, today these childhood pleasures evoke for her the tastes and textures of growing up.
This memoir is both an enormously appealing account of an unusual childhood and a testament to the power of food to prompt memory, vividly bringing to life a lost time and place. Included here are recipes for more than thirty delicious dishes that are recovered from Jaffrey’s childhood.
results.how_to_find_us: Book on the table
results.name: Climbing the Mango Trees: A Memoir of a Childhood in India @ Masala Art, Needham

results.description:
For this trip, I’m going to try to build a crew with some members who haven’t been on the water yet, or not very recently. The weather should not be a factor Saturday, so strong sailing experience won’t be needed this time out. Sign on to the waitlist when it opens at noon Thursday and I’ll sort out and respond to the RSVPs depending on conditions as the weekend gets closer, no later than Friday morning.

The vessel is a cruising 34’ sailboat with a galley stove, teakettle, table, sink and head (toilet). There is a windscreen to make the cockpit a little more comfortable this time of year, and plenty of room down below to get out of the wind and sun. Pans and utensils are aboard if anyone wants to heat up a lunch down below. We’ll eat at anchor tucked behind one of the islands, unless the seasonal moorings are placed by the weekend.

Note: RSVP only if you can be there rain or shine. No-shows and late cancellations that cost someone else on the waitlist a seat will not be considered for future trips.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet under the arch at the Boston Harbor Hotel
results.name: New members harbor sail

results.description:
A beautiful 1,782 acre park with hiking trails and ponds, as well as the Ames Mansion, a gothic stone home built in 1910, Borderland has wonderful views and varied landscape, making for an enjoyable outing. 

After hiking and working up an appetite, we'll head a short ride (6.8 MIles) up the street to StoneForge for some lunch.

We'll meet at the visitor's center ($5 parking per vehicle).

Bring: Water and hiking boots, check weather and dress accordingly for temperatures forecast.

See you there!

For more info on Borderland:http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/borderland/index.htm

Info on StoneForge: 

http://www.stoneforgerestaurants.com/grill/ 

Lunch Menu til 4 PM:

http://www.stoneforgerestaurants.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Grill-Lunch-Menu1.pdf


From Your Organizer:

There is a suggested voluntary donation of $2 per person to help cover the administrative fees of this Meetup page, and can be made day of the hike.

It's spring; time to re-connect & to welcome in the energy of renewal of hopes and dreams; make it happen! 

Join us for an all-afternoon and all-evening affair where we bring together several communities of like-hearted folks who are interested in having better quality of life to connect, learn, laugh, introspect, make friends, dance, and create deeply satisfying, authentic relationships. 

You'll leave empowered, invigorated, connected, and energized.

(Suzy Spivey, Daring to Dream™) 
Click here to RSVP

(Sarah Rose, Crystal Transitions Coaching)  
Click here to RSVP

* Mindfulness: It’s Not What You Think. 
(Mary Ann Christie Burnside, The Mindfulness Studio) 
Click here to RSVP 

************************************************** 

7:30 - 10:30 PM: Party Time! Heart-to-Heart Community Social

Mingle, dance, and connect. There'll be fun activities that will deepen connections & spark meaningful friendships. It's for everyone, not just for singles. 

The party will feature:

* Authentic Relating Games  
Invite your "inner child" to play and have fun while connecting with lots of people in an authentic way. The secret to joy is play!  From heights of joy and heart-pounding fun to meditative depths of presence, these highly interactive games allow you to explore ways of seeing, connecting, and appreciating yourself and others lovingly and authentically. 

(ChewHoong Koh) 

* Journey Dance  
Guiding you to reconnect with your innate state of joyful well being and celebrate LIFE! 

(Suzy Spivey, Daring to Dream™) 

* Dance, Dance, mingle...Dance...make friends...

results.name: Battle for the Quickening

results.description:
Making decisions, especially the BIG ones, is not easy. Do you ever make the safe choice even when your gut is telling you otherwise? How do you make sure you don't stay stuck in a rut (maybe for years -yikes) because you're not sure what to do? 

Tap into your intuitive well of wisdom that guides you through all of life’s challenges. Never again will you feel lost when faced with an important decision. 

You will learn:

(1) Why making decisions just with your rational brain is a bad idea

(2) How to tap into your inner well of wisdom with Intuitive MoJo

3) How to have new confidence that your decisions are the best ones for you...hell yeah!

About Deborah Helen, PhD:

Deborah Helen is an educator-turned-life coach, who helps people achieve the life they were meant to lead. She uses the latest in brain research and cognitive psychology to develop innovative approaches to better living.

www.deborahhelen.com

**************************************************

Enjoy the full day mini-Expo and Social for only: $10 

Make sure you secure a spot before it sells out!

Save money and pay ahead of time for the full day and night: 
 bit.ly/PUYL-MU051416

(Price at the door: $15)

Deborah's miniWorkshop is just one offering during our all-day PUYL mini-Expo.  You can enjoy this miniWorkshop, as well as the many other miniWorkshops, and the party afterwards, for one low price.  (The Power Up Your Life miniExpo takes place 12:45 - 7:30, and the Social is 7:30-10:30 pm.)

This event is being announced at lots of other places. The RSVPs don't reflect the total attendees.  Go ahead and secure a spot; come and play with us ;o) 

**************************************************

Click here to see all the other events you will enjoy during this jam-packed day at the mini-Expo and jam-packed night at the Social.

results.name: PUYL: Intuitive MoJo to Make Life Decisions that Make You Go "Hell, Yeah"

results.description:
Well, it looks like todays weather is much better than last weekend so I've decided to schedule this event again. 

Planning on going to dinner after 5PM for those who are interested.  Just send me a message or email with YES - I'm interested in dinner afterwards.

No entrance fee to the State Park at this time.

Let's put those sneakers and hike another section of Hopkinton State Park and for those who want to be a kid again bring your kite and outdoor yard games. 

  PLEASE READ ALL OF THE INFORMATION BELOW.

As you enter the park, turn LEFT and follow the route towards the MAIN BEACH AREA. There is very large parking lot at the Main Beach Area and several others close by.  See the map below with all the details.

If you have signed up to join us and your plans change, please UPDATE your RSVP.  PLEASE DON'T BE A NO SHOW! 

It only takes a few minutes to change your RSVP to NO and to send a quick message.

Outdoor yards games and hike may be happening at the same time. So do whatever you prefer or both.  Volunteers needed to lead the hikes.

 See the map below for the exact meet-up location.

For the online map - click the link below.

http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/hopkinton.pdf

Note: There is NO Alcohol allowed nor any littering at the State Park.

Public Bathrooms will be available on the premises.

Shown below are some of the outdoor yard games that I will be providing.

See the instructions and video of how to play the game. If the games are of interest please take the time to learn as much about the game as possible before you arrive.  It's been several years since I've played some of these games and I don't remember as much as I use too :-)!

Have you ever play Kubb?

Kubb is a lawn game where the object is to knock over wooden blocks by throwing wooden sticks at them. Kubb can be simply described as a combination of bowling and horseshoes. The ultimate object of the game is to knock the "king" over, before the opponent does.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liMZ-dFMJSc

How about Cornhole?

Scoring is simple. After all bags have been thrown, a bag remaining on the board is worth 1 point. A bag that went in the hole is worth 3 points. Add up how many points you earned and compare them to your opponents. Equal points cancel each other out so that only one team can score per round. For example, if you scored 5 points and your opponent scored 3, you will add 2 points to your overall score and your team will throw first in the next round. If you scored 6 points and your opponent scored 6 as well, there will be no points awarded and whoever threw first in the last round will throw first again. A game is won when a team reaches 21 points with a lead of 2 or more points. The first team to win 2 games wins the match.

Ladder Game

Ladder Game, space the game ladders about 15 feet apart and start tossing your bolas. Each player tosses all 3 bolas, then the next player tosses all 3 bolas. The first one to 21 without going over is the winner! The top rung is worth 3 points, middle is 2 and bottom rung is 1 point.

Horsehoes

Horsehoes, there are two ways to score: by throwing "ringers" or by throwing the horseshoe nearest to the stake. A ringer is a thrown horseshoe such that the horseshoe completely encircles the stake. Disputes are settled by using a straightedge to touch the two points at the ends of the horseshoe, called "heel calks". If the straightedge doesn't touch the stake, then the horseshoe is a ringer.

Kickball - Let's act like kids again and have some fun playing this game!

results.description:
By signing up you agree to and have read the Mosaic Outdoor Mountain Club release of Liability. To read waiver please go to the Mosaic Pages of our website.

On this walk we will first checkout the flowers in the public garden. A must see this time of year.

Of all the flowers in today’s Public Garden, it is the tulips that have the oldest and closest tie with its history, going back to its earliest years and continuing, with variations, until the present day. The prize tulips that bloomed around 1840 were said to be the first such display in America. The bulbs were imported from England at a cost of $1,500, a huge sum in those days. Now an iconic image of the Garden, the blooming of 26,000 tulips in the spring is one of the most photographed views in Boston. Don't forget your camera!

Then move on over to the Arthur Fiedler bridge for a stroll along the Charles River Walkway. This part will be a loop over the Mass. Ave bridge to Memorial drive. Down to the Longfellow and back over to where we started on the Boston side.

Route may be altered at anytime by group request.

After we can also decide on a place for coffee or food.

results.description:
Well, it looks like todays weather is much better than last weekend so I've decided to schedule this event again. 

Planning on going to dinner after 5PM for those who are interested.  Just send me a message or email with YES - I'm interested in dinner afterwards.

No entrance fee to the State Park at this time.

Let's put those sneakers and hike another section of Hopkinton State Park and for those who want to be a kid again bring your kite and outdoor yard games. 

                  PLEASE READ ALL OF THE INFORMATION BELOW.

As you enter the park, turn LEFT and follow the route towards the MAIN BEACH AREA. There is very large parking lot at the Main Beach Area and several others close by.  See the map below with all the details.

If you have signed up to join us and your plans change, please UPDATE your RSVP.  PLEASE DON'T BE A NO SHOW! 

It only takes a few minutes to change your RSVP to NO and to send a quick message.

Outdoor yards games and hike may be happening at the same time. So do whatever you prefer or both.  Volunteers needed to lead the hikes.

 See the map below for the exact meet-up location.

For the online map - click the link below.

http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/hopkinton.pdf

Note: There is NO Alcohol allowed nor any littering at the State Park.

Public Bathrooms will be available on the premises.

Shown below are some of the outdoor yard games that I will be providing.

See the instructions and video of how to play the game. If the games are of interest please take the time to learn as much about the game as possible before you arrive.  It's been several years since I've played some of these games and I don't remember as much as I use too :-)!

Have you ever play Kubb?

Kubb is a lawn game where the object is to knock over wooden blocks by throwing wooden sticks at them. Kubb can be simply described as a combination of bowling and horseshoes. The ultimate object of the game is to knock the "king" over, before the opponent does.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liMZ-dFMJSc

How about Cornhole?

Scoring is simple. After all bags have been thrown, a bag remaining on the board is worth 1 point. A bag that went in the hole is worth 3 points. Add up how many points you earned and compare them to your opponents. Equal points cancel each other out so that only one team can score per round. For example, if you scored 5 points and your opponent scored 3, you will add 2 points to your overall score and your team will throw first in the next round. If you scored 6 points and your opponent scored 6 as well, there will be no points awarded and whoever threw first in the last round will throw first again. A game is won when a team reaches 21 points with a lead of 2 or more points. The first team to win 2 games wins the match.

Ladder Game

Ladder Game, space the game ladders about 15 feet apart and start tossing your bolas. Each player tosses all 3 bolas, then the next player tosses all 3 bolas. The first one to 21 without going over is the winner! The top rung is worth 3 points, middle is 2 and bottom rung is 1 point.

Horsehoes 

Horsehoes, there are two ways to score: by throwing "ringers" or by throwing the horseshoe nearest to the stake. A ringer is a thrown horseshoe such that the horseshoe completely encircles the stake. Disputes are settled by using a straightedge to touch the two points at the ends of the horseshoe, called "heel calks". If the straightedgedoesn't touch the stake, then the horseshoe is a ringer. 

Kickball - Let's act like kids again and have some fun playing this game!   

Have any questions?  Just give me a call, send a message or email: [masked]   I don't want to post my cell phone number on this site, but will email to you.  

Organizer assumes no liability either before, during, or after this event.

**Back by popular demand**

Are you new to knitting, crochet, or needle crafts? Want to work on your latest project with other progressive-minded crafters? Join us at the Panera Bread in Porter Square for Stitching for Justice on Saturday, May 14th from 2-5 pm! 

Crocheters, knitters, spinners, cross-stitchers, embroiderers and quilters are welcome, regardless of your skill level. 

So look no further if you're seeking like-minded folks to share patterns and techniques with, want to cross-promote your events and campaigns while you knit one purl one or finish off your latest granny square, or if you are new to the area and looking for groups to get involved in. 

Mind's Eye Yarns is right across the parking lot from our meeting place, so if you need more yarn or spinning fiber, or a new hook or needles for your latest project, you can easily pick up what you need on your way to Stitching for Justice.


If you want to build a strong cross-issue social justice movement, Socializing for Justice is for you. Arrive by yourself or bring a friend. Newcomers always welcomed.


Please note that this Panera is located in Porter Square shopping center. There is a large parking lot and it's very close to Porter Square T stop. Panera offers a wide variety of sandwiches, salads, baked goods and beverages (with free refills). Check out their menu. 


_________________________________________________________

SOCIALIZING FOR JUSTICE - www.sojust.org
SoJust is all about building a cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community, network and movement in Boston based on the philosophy of abundance. We're doing it by putting the SOCIAL back in SOCIAL JUSTICE. We focus on creating welcoming spaces that foster relationship-building across issue silos.

SoJust isn't a non-profit 501(c)(3). We're a grassroots, volunteer-run, member-supported, cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community that's been growing steadily since August 2006. We have 2900+ members, hosted over 215 events, and manage an online hub of progressive events and resources at www.sojust.org.

results.description:
A good photograph is knowing where to stand.” – Ansel Adams 


Learn how to see nature through the eyes of an artist. Create photos that capture the natural wonders of the Arnold Arboretum in your own unique way. The lilacs are in bloom! Last weekend was the official Lilac Sunday so I expect there will be fewer people there this week. And the cold weather has put the bloom behind schedule which is perfect for us.

About your instructor: Suzanne Merritt is a master level instructor with a studio at the Boston Center for the Arts. She has led workshops on beauty, photography, and creativity in Asia, Europe and the United States for the past 20 years. She was the founder of the Polaroid Creativity and Innovation Lab. She recently opened The Curious Soul Photo School in Boston MA.

Yes you can always go to the Arboretum on your own on with a free meetup group just for fun.But if you spend time with a professional instructor, you  receive specific guidance and exercises designed to improve your photography right away. Learning to see creatively means slowing down to notice simple details right in front of you the have the potential to make a great photo. The things other people walk right by will suddenly jump out at you begging for your attention.

 I will introduce you to some simple step by step practices for creative seeing so you can find beauty in the most unexpected places. I will show you some inspiring example photos to help get you started. I will help challenge your assumptions about what makes an interesting photo.

I have designed a series of three specific assignments to challenge your creativity and get you out of your habitual ways of seeing. We will start with macro, then mid range and end with landscapes. You will also have some free time to just wander on your own or with a photo buddy.

You will have a chance to try these out right away with my guidance out on the grounds.  You will receive individual coaching and critique while we are in the field shooting. This way you can be confident that you will be able to repeat the process next time you are out on a shoot.

We will work with color, texture, pattern, and light to make our photos come to life. As always, this is a non technical jargon zone. It is all about the creative act of seeing and capturing the moments of life with a fresh eye. There is a sudden sense of discovery when you get a glimpse of nature in this way.

This workshop is for you if:

• You want to develop your eye to see beyond the basic, obvious images.

• You would like to go off auto and explore depth of field with aperture priority.

• Your photos are “nice” but not jaw dropping all that often. 

• You would like to go beyond the basics of composition and learn more advanced ways of composing your images using dynamic tension and harmony.

Taking better photos takes practice and with guidance the you know what to focus on and how to see with the creative eye of an art photographer.


I am very excited about offering this intensive workshop. I know you will leave with 5 new tips and techniques for seeing creatively that you will be able to apply to any type of photography you do in the future. Handouts will be provided.

The $45.00 tuition for the workshop 

The closest T stop Forest Hills on the Orange Line. More details will be provided once you RSVP for the workshop. There are also several parking lots in the area. Check the website of the Arnold Arboretum for directions. http://www.arboretum.harvard.edu

We are going to have a great time! You have joined the group, now join the fun. RSVP right away to hold your space. I look forward to seeing you Saturday May 14 from 2:00 to 6:00.

 Once you reserve your space you will receive an email with more details about what to wear and what to bring.

Suzanne

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4
