results.description:
Third Annual Sakadawa Interfaith Celebration

Saturday May 14, 2:00 to 5:00 pm

Kurukulla Center is excited to announce the third annual Sakadawa Interfaith Celebration!

This is our third year of coming together in celebration and prayers for world peace and harmony.  Join us among friends from all religions to celebrate Buddha's birth, 2,634 years ago, on Saturday May 14th from 2:00 to 5:00 pm.

Sakadawa, falling on the fourth full moon after the Tibetan New Year, is the day we commemorate Buddha's birth, enlightenment and passing. Astrologically, it is a time when the energy two weeks before and two weeks after the full moon is greatly increased. The day of the actual full moon - Sakadawa - is incredibly auspicious. There is great benefit for your spiritual practice to be especially engaged in positive actions, as much as you can on this day! 

We had a packed house for our celebration last year and expect to have one again this year!

The celebration is a chance to support the important work of Kurukulla Center. An important mission of the Center is to fulfill the wishes of His Holiness the Dalai Lama and as such His Holiness encourages his students and others to have interfaith dialogue and gatherings with brothers and sisters of different faiths. This is a beautiful way to nourish our community and ourselves.

Please help support the Center so we can continue to offer events like this and other important occasions to the community-at-large.
results.name: Third Annual Sakadawa Interfaith Celebration

group.name: Kurukulla Center for Tibetan Buddhist Studies

results.description:
Art plus M & M = win win! Co-posted to Boston Cultural Nomads.

This is NOT a tour, it is a socializer. If you want to go on a tour, please do so on your own... 

CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets, and Meet & Greet then at 2:45 we're OFF!   
   
For the 11th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor. Then we go into the Tobey Gallery right there & pass through to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight (image below-- the man in the painting who is pursuing her is not in this image which defines it), Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel (image below), The incredible Call to Arms mini study sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones's works.  And don't forget the room for the great 16th cent. sculptor statuettes by Bernini.
   
NOTE-- hosts will not linger at some of the galleries but PASS RIGHT THROUGH  others because there will be MUCH MORE to see after this.  So GO! stay with the company. This is a meetup enjoy the company; if you want to come earlier to linger at your fav places do that then.  

At 4 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the hosts) --note the weird sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir and other masterpieces --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria. 

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 to Felipe's in Harvard Square. That is a 15 minute walk through Harvard Yard.  

HEADS UP the cafeteria closes at 4 PM! But if you sneak in your own beverage from your locker nobody will be checking ...
   
ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.

http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-7he8jlARtuM/VJmDezIHhRI/AAAAAAAEzwg/v9Rn311tEa8/s288/DSC00954.JPG

What does it mean to "have a voice?" The roots of voice originate in the spirit and soul. Voice allows us to define and express who we truly are and live powerfully in the world.

You will learn:
- A powerful tool to connect and to know your voice
- Fun ways to play with your voice for deeper connection and expression

About Linda Marks:

For more than 30 years Linda Marks has coached people all over the world on "The Power of Voice," which can include the singing voice, but also explores the deeper sense of what "Voice" is and what it means to "have a voice" or "find your voice," to have full power, presence and expression in the world. 

She is also an author, a psychotherapist and life coach, using emotional-kinesthetic psychotherapy (EKP), the heart-centered body psychotherapy method she created,
empowering individuals, couples, groups and families. 

Linda is also a professional singer/songwriter and cabaret singer. She has performed in major music venues in Boston including Scullers Jazz Club, Club Cafe and Ryles Jazz Club, and has appeared on radio and tv.

results.description:
This looks cool, and Groupon to boot. 

 https://www.groupon.com/deals/schooner-fame-2-9

 https://www.zerve.com/amp/view_activity.php?activity_id=3032&event_id=3903336

Modeled after its eponymous ancestor, which sailed in the War of 1812, the present-day schoonerFame cruises up and down the coast and the harbor around Salem during trips that last an hour and 45 minutes. The trips run three times a day, seven days a week in the summer, and passengers slog down beers ($5 onboard) throughout their outing. Public sails depart from Pickering Wharf in downtown Salem. Check the schedule for more info.

Schooner "Fame"

Captain William Webb bellowed to his crewmen, "Ready cannons, bring her to starboard!" as they rounded on the English ship Concord. He wasn't born a soldier, but the English had press-ganged some of his closest friends into slavery on their warships, stolen his family's livelihood, and set his home of Salem, Massachusetts, on the path to financial ruin. Like many other merchants, fishermen, and ship owners, Webb and his crew outfitted whatever boats they could find to fight the English during the War of 1812, and the 70-foot Fame was no exception. The original Fame went on 11 more journeys before being wrecked in 1814 and now lives on as a luxurious home for the retired actors ofThe Little Mermaid.


Some of the things you may see during our sail are:


Salem from the water!Winter IslandFort PickeringFive lighthouses: Derby Wharf, Fort Pickering, Hospital Point, Baker's Island and Marblehead NeckMagnificent waterfront homes in Beverly and MarbleheadThe outlying islands: Misery, Baker's, Eagle, Children's, and the RockAnd you'll see them from a beautifully maintained 

authentic wooden schooner

 which personifies Salem's storied past.

Take the tiller, help raise the sails, or just sit back and watch the world glide past. 

It's a different world out on the water.

What Is Not Included?

Food and beverages

 are not included, but are for sale on board at reasonable prices.  We offer beer, wine, soft drinks, water and assorted snacks. Guests are encouraged to bring their own snacks and sandwiches, but no alcohol can be brought on board due to state regulations.


Meeting LocationPickering Wharf Marina (Salem, MA)(Exact meeting location details will be provided immediately upon purchase of tickets.)
results.how_to_find_us: $21   for one   ($35 value)   $39  for two on the schooner Fame ($70 value)
results.name: Salem Triple (Schooner Ride) - "Fame" - Salem, MA

results.description:
We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are very few RSVPs.

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or Chinatown on the Orange Line.
Also a short walk from Park Street or Downtown Crossing. 

• From Boylston Station, go south on Tremont Street (away from Boston Common),  then take a right onto Stuart Street.  The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

• From Chinatown Station, go west on Boylston Street (toward Boston Common), then take a left onto Tremont Street. Turn right onto Stuart Street. The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

There is a map of the area below. If you have trouble finding us, please feel free to call or text me at[masked]-2923.  Also you can call or text if you come after we have left for Chinatown, although then there is a greater chance I will miss the call.

Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

The Meetup does not end at 6 - instead, some time around there, we usually go out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards to eat family style - anyone who wants to come is welcome. The cost is usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks for which people pay their own way).  We are open to restaurant suggestions.  However, I am not willing to get into dividing up large numbers of orders on one giant check, which is why we generally go to Chinatown and split everything down the middle.  If you don't want to eat at all, you can come and just enjoy the company for free.  

Please BRING CASH if you can and want to go to dinner - many of the restaurants limit cards to two per table, so if a lot of people have no cash it can be a problem.

Stuart Street view
results.how_to_find_us: We usually have several tables pulled together at the highest point of the food court nearest the elevator.
results.name: Saturday Social Meetup at City Place

results.description:
Our bodies are a reservoir of knowledge, holding all of our dreams and aspirations as well as all of the buried feelings/emotions and hurt that sabotage those dreams.  These trapped feelings and emotions can be likened to a virus in our computer system.  They run in the background to slow things down, erase data, and can eventually crash our system if not removed.  

Until you can fully feel the hurt and trapped emotions that have been buried, they will continue to operate within you and sabotage your life.  

Using somatic movement practices, you will:

· Become aware of the feeling state that is driving your system

· Bring acceptance and deep understanding to your inner process

· Begin to heal the hurt and release the trapped emotions that sabotage you

· Clear your system to manifest your dreams

About Suzy Spivey:

Suzy Spivey, founder of Daring to Dream™, is a certified coach, speaker, and registered somatic movement therapist. She is committed to helping people live more fully, with purpose, meaning and joy. She specializes in guiding people through life transitions, mid-life re-designs and transformational healing. Start now and see what’s really possible for your life!   

www.suzyspivey.com

results.description:
This will be a blind tasting of higher end White Burgundies with bottles at $60+

Please read through the information below regarding the $30 deposit requirement.

There’s something about White Burgundies.  Lush.  Dry.  Majestic.  They have wide range.  Some are flinty and mineral while others are oaky and rich.  They are provocative; a thinker's wine.  No wines are as terroir sensitive as these; each bottle captures distinctly the specific flavors and elements of the land and environment. Though the quality of wines at all price points from this region have improved in the last few decades, it is unquestionably the ones above a certain price point and level that offer a more sublime experience.

Listed below are the 4 main regions in Burgundy (and the villages within each one) that produce white wines.  Chablis and Côte de Beaune produce most of the higher end white wines, but Côte Chalonnaise and Mâconnais have some good ones too, though harder to find.  They are almost always made from chardonnay.

• Chablis

• Côte de Beaune (the southern part of the Côte d’Or)

o  Meursault

o  Puligny-Montrachet

o  Chassagne-Montrachet

o  Corton-Charlemagne


o  Auxey-Duresses

o  Beaune

• Côte Chalonnaise

o  Rully

o  Montagny

• Mâconnais

o  Pouilly-Fuissé

o  Vergisson

o  Saint Véran

Note: Though Beaujolais is technically a part of Burgundy, we are excluding wines from there.

PLEASE NOTE: This will be a free wine tasting.  When you RSVP, you will be put on a waitlist.  In order to move on to the RSVP list, you must put down a $30 deposit in advance via Paypal; I will send my Paypal information to those on the waitlist in the order received, and upon payment, your RSVP will be confirmed.  At the night of the tasting, we will refund you $30 when you show up. There will be no refunds for cancellations and no shows.  The only way to get a refund is to show up at the tasting. Please only RSVP if you know you will be attending.

For this tasting, please bring the following:

• 1 bottle of white burgundy $60+

• 4 wine glasses

• 1 quality food item that will pair well with these higher quality wines
results.name: High End White Burgundies

results.description:
Experience the 50's and the next decade all over again.  Immerse yourself in the style and harmony of the era.

The Backtrack Band will take us there. 


Backtrack Band Video


Whereas big band/swing music placed the primary emphasis on the orchestration, post-war/early 1950s era Pop focused on the song’s story and/or the emotion being expressed. By the early 1950s, emotional delivery had reached its apex in the miniature psycho-drama songs of writer-singer Johnnie Ray. Known as "The Cry Guy" and "The Prince of Wails", Ray's on-stage emotion wrought "breakdowns" provided a release for the pent-up angst of his predominantly teenage fans.</a> As Ray described it, "I make them feel, I exhaust them, I destroy them." It was during this period that the fan hysteria, which began with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Sinatra">Frank Sinatra during the Second World War, really began to take hold.

The  1950's Dance will be held  at the Four Points by Sheraton  Boston Hotel in Wakefield, MA. Saturday, May 14,  7 - 11pm,  guests $30.


Wear 50's clothes.  Immerse yourself in this era.  Feel it, Hear it, Wear it.

http://www.bing.com/images/search?q=50%27s+clothes+pictures&FORM=HDRSC2

Passed hors d'oeuvres will be served. Dessert, assorted fruit, coffee and tea are included. There is a cash bar. Free Parking. 

See the lower page for directions - http://www.fourpointswakefieldboston.com/
results.how_to_find_us: Front hotel entrance to the left, down the stairs
results.name: The 1950's Dance

results.description:
Mindfulness has been transforming lives, for centuries.  It’s not about clearing our minds, although it brings clarity.  It’s not about blissing out, though practice creates contentment.  And it’s not about stress reduction, though it can significantly reduce stress. Join us to learn what mindfulness is and isn’t.  Come experience it for yourself. 



About Mary Ann Christie Burnside, Ed.D:


Mary Ann is a developmental psychologist with a speciality in mindfulness and positive psychology. She has studied and practiced mindfulness for 13 years and created The Mindfulness Studio where she welcomes adults, children and families to explore and practice mindfulness.  Mary Ann is currently working on her first book.

www.themindfulnessstudio.com

**************************************************

Enjoy the full day mini-Expo and Social for only: $10 


Mary Ann's miniWorkshop is just one offering during our all-day PUYL mini-Expo.  You can enjoy this miniWorkshop, as well as the many other miniWorkshops, and the party afterwards, for one low price.  (The Power Up Your Life miniExpo takes place 12:45 -7:30, and the Social is 7:30-10:30 pm.)

Please save money and pay ahead of time for the full day and night at: 
 bit.ly/PUYL-MU051416

(Price at the door: $15)

This event is being announced at lots of other places. The RSVPs don't reflect the total attendees.  Go ahead and secure a spot at bit.ly/PUYL-MU051416; come and play with us ;o) 

**************************************************

Click here to see all the other events you will enjoy during this jam-packed day at the mini-Expo and jam-packed night at the Social.
results.how_to_find_us: free or cheap parking; $10 to enjoy lots of events between 12:45 pm - 10:30 pm
results.name: PUYL: Mindfulness: It’s Not What You Think

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court. There are two individual bathrooms that some people change in. Some people come prepared to play, while others change.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers/Karaoke nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Be sure to bring socks with you in order to play and no $20 bills please!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58
results.name: Dodge The Ball! - Play Dodgeball With Us!

results.description:
By signing up and/or attending a Boston Area Photography Group meetup you agree to the Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer below.

No guests are permitted on Boston Area Photography Group events. Please have your guests join our Meetup. 

MEETUP DESCRIPTION:  May 14th 7:30 p.m. on the front stairs entrance to the Museum of Science. We will walk across the street to the North Point Park as we make our way through the park taking photos we will go under the zakim bridge and then to the Charlestown bridge to take photos. Afterwards we will walk down to the Lovejoy Wharf stopping to take more photos before crossing the walkway at the locks. After crossing the walkway we will continue to take photos under the zakim bridge and then returning to North Point Park in darkness. My best estimate is the total round trip is no more than 1.5 miles. Great locations to photograph the zakim bridge. The museum of science is easy access by the t and parking can be found at the Museum or at the CambridgeSide Galleria.

Remember: we are volunteers. You are responsible for your own safety and enjoyment.

Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: 
By using this site, you hereby RELEASE and DISCHARGE it's owners, principals, affiliates, presenters, organizer, hosts and participants from any and all liability, claims, demands or causes of action that you now have, or may have in the future, for injuries, damages, death and/or economic loss of any kind or nature, arising in whole or in
results.how_to_find_us: On the front steps of the Museum of Science
results.name: Zakim Bridge from both Cambridge North Point Park and Charlestown Bridge

** Be aware, our last FOUR SHOWS SOLD OUT. You can purchase advance tickets with NO FEE here:
http://www.theriottheater.com/laughing-liberally-boston.html With the 2016 Presidential primaries in high gear, with Donald Trump and Ted Cruz saying crazy and insulting things on a nearly daily basis, we need progressive laughs now more than ever. That's why we have Laughing Liberally Boston, a monthly progressive political comedy show featuring some Boston’s top liberal and progressive comedians. Comedians on the May 14th bill include: Christine An, Phoebe Angle, Scott Kremer, Pamela Ross, and Jiayong Li. Hosted by Matthew Filipowicz.

In addition to some of the finest progressive comedians Boston has to offer, each Laughing Liberally Boston show will feature a special interview segment with a local political figure, journalist or activist. This month’s guest is Karen Chen. Karen is the co-director of the Chinese Progressive Association, a grassroots community organization working for full equality and and empowerment of Boston's Chinese community and against gentrification in Boston's Chinatown. For more info on CPA, visit http://cpaboston.org/. Laughing Liberally Boston takes place the second Saturday of every month, with the next show on Saturday May 14th at 8pm at the Riot Theater, 146a South Street, Jamaica Plain, MA. Admission is $8. More info and advance tickets can be found at http://laughingliberallyboston.tumblr.com

results.description:
In the 3D animated comedy, The Angry Birds Movie, we'll finally find out why the birds are so angry. The movie takes us to an island populated entirely by happy, flightless birds – or almost entirely. In this paradise, Red (Jason Sudeikis, We're the Millers, Horrible Bosses), a bird with a temper problem, speedy Chuck (Josh Gad in his first animated role since Frozen), and the volatile Bomb (Danny McBride, This is the End, Eastbound and Down) have always been outsiders. But when the island is visited by mysterious green piggies, it’s up to these unlikely outcasts to figure out what the pigs are up to.

PG

results.description:
Fantasy. Multiverse. Marvel. Imagination. Sci-fi. Drama. Doctor Who. Mystery. Lord of the Rings. Creativity. Batman. Anime. One piece. Harry Potter. Star Wars. Final Fantasy. Fiction. Parallel universes. Exploration. Horror. Magic. Art. Poetry. Creativity. Anything that catches your attention? Discover an ongoing expansive fictional universe. 
Experience the world of Zenkora on May 14, 8:30PM. RVSP here for free. Reception after concert! 
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/zenkora-a-brief-history-tickets-22664453992 
Learn more about Zenkora here. 
https://www.facebook.com/zenkora

"Imagine a world of Lord of the Rings. And StarWars. And Star Trek, Harry Potter, Doctor Who, Sherlock Holmes, The Matrix, Terminator, Back to The Future, The Avengers. Now imagine them all together, and more. That is the scope and the dream of Zenkora - an unlimited universe of fantasy stories and settings." Zenkora: A Brief History, is a creative multi-media concert centered on exploring the stories, features, and characters from an original fantasy universe. Narrative elements, an extensive original soundtrack, and a wide range of illustrations come together to present a cohesive vision of this universe and its countless facets and storylines, which include a virtually limitless variety of settings and genres. The concert will be presenting various collaborations between art forms such as dance, drama, poetry, and visual art, while the backbone of the concert is a full orchestral score.

“We are passionate about creativity and imagination. About exploration. Zenkora will open audiences to the possibility of exploring and contributing their personal creativity to building an original fantasy universe. We wish its stories, characters, music, artworks will bring a sense of passion and excitement to people’s lives.” #reachingbeyondimagination
results.name: Discover a NEW original fantasy multiverse: Zenkora

The NE Season Opener at Hopkinton State Park is the best kickoff race to the season. Your choice: Duathlon or Triathlon! results.description:
Once you register on Southborough Recreation Sports Meetup you can RSVP to play in all the Meetups you want. The $15 per month fee will be collected when you show up to play and will cover you for that month.

Doubles, Mixed Doubles, Singles matches will be played on outdoor hard-courts. All levels 3.0 and higher welcome. You must be able to serve over-head, volley and rally. New tennis balls for each court will be provided.

Based on play level you indicated in your profile initially you will be matched up with similar level players. Adjustment to level may be done based on actual play. Players participating in a session will be emailed the day before with court assignment. You decide on starting teams on each court.

All guests must also register, RSVP and pay the fee to participate. This will ensure we have a spot for your guest...matched to players of similar skill-level.

1st Session matches are from 8:00-8:50AM and 8:50-9:30AM. 2nd Session matches are from 9:30-10:15AM and 10:15-11:00AM. You must RSVP to both sessions if you wish to play from 8AM to 11AM. Matches are w/Ad scoring. Leading team moves up & splits. Other team moves down & splits.

Occasionally, we will have to play at other locations on days ARHS has events. Organizer will change location on the meetup description.

Rain and/or wet courts may force cancellation which will be communicated via e-mail as early as possible.

All players play at their own risk at all times.

Organizers reserve the right to remove any player from the RSVP list or this social tennis Group or the courts at any time for any reason without advance notice.

results.name: Southborough Recreation Tennis @ Fay School - Sunday 8:00-9:30AM

The Boston Brain Tumor Ride is event to raise awareness and much-needed resources to fund critical brain tumor-specific programs to improve the lives of all those affected by brain tumors. Hosted by the National Brain Tumor Society, the Boston Brain Tumor Ride offers individuals and teams a chance to honor and remember loved ones, connect with others interested in the brain tumor cause, and helps to educate the local community on the diverse needs of the brain tumor community.

We will have great food, an exciting program and fun activities during the day, so come join us for a memorable day! 

To volunteer for this event or to view volunteer descriptions, please visit our website for more information! http://events.braintumor.org/events/boston-brain-tumor-ride/volunteer-roles/

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us at [masked]. Please use "Boston Ride" in the e-mail subject line.

Volunteer shift: 8:30AM - 2:00PM (can be half day too).

results.description:
MAASBESA in collaboration with Mr. Faton Limani is organizing a fundraising event to support the Albanian School at UMass Boston.


Faton (see his short bio below) will teach two two-hour intensive workshop modules based on the Adaptive Leadership framework developed by Professor Ronald Heifetz and Professor Marty Linsky at Harvard University. This course consistently wins the alumni award for most influential courses at the Harvard Kennedy School and draws students from throughout Harvard’s graduate schools and neighboring universities. This workshop is designed for professionals with diverse backgrounds and from various sectors.

See who is going and please invite your friends. 

https://www.facebook.com/events/221453201563730/


The purpose of the workshop is to increase the capacity of participants to exercise leadership with or without authority from different positions in organization or in community. Participants will learn about difference between leadership and authority, how to exercise leadership with or without authority, technical vs. adaptive challenges, diagnosing the system, analyzing leadership cases using the concepts and tools introduced in this workshop, etc. We will also go through different diagnostics tools for analyzing the complexity of change in social systems and strategies for action. The workshop will be based on the modern methods of teachings such as: cases and case in point learning. Please RSVP and address any questions to [masked]


Faton Limani, Leadership Development Coach & Consultant


Faton is passionate about teaching and using Adaptive Leadership across sectors to help individuals and organizations address their challenges and solve difficult problems. Faton graduated from the Harvard Kennedy School (HKS) in 2014 with a Masters in Public Administration.

After graduating from HKS, Faton has worked at the school as a Teaching Assistant in 2014 for the Edward S. Mason Program Summer Seminar and the Mid-Career Summer Seminar, where he supported in their learning more than 200 Mid-Career students from more then 100 different countries. Since Fall 2014 Faton has been working at Harvard Kennedy School as a Head Teaching Assistant for Adaptive Leadership course taught by Professors Ronald Heifetz, Timothy O’Brien, and Hugh O’Doherty. During this time he has coached over 100 students in their personal leadership cases and challenges and managed teaching teams supporting more than 400 students. During this period he has also worked as a Teaching Fellow of Adaptive Leadership for Harvard Asia Center, where he taught more then 100 participants from different sectors in four different countries in Asia.

Prior to Harvard, Faton worked in Kosovo and Iraq as a civil contractor for the US Department of Defense for more then ten years. After returning to Kosovo, he worked as a Teaching Assistant for a Strategic Management course at the College for International Management – Globus and was engaged in local politics, non-profit and private sector organizations in a variety of roles.

Faton also holds an MS in Economics and BS in Management and Informatics from University of Prishtina, Kosovo.

Please note that the workshop will be offered for free, but we welcome donations from participants to support the Albanian Language and Heritage School at UMass.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/fatonlimani
results.how_to_find_us: Room 207 McCormack Hall University of Massachusetts Boston
results.name: Leadership Workshop organized by MAASBESA and Harvard Graduate Faton Limani

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to one of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Moriah. We will use Stoney Brook Trail and Carter Moriah Trail to get to the summit. We will then retrace our steps to get back to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people.

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.1 miles and climb about 3,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 45 minutes to complete (this doesn't include time taking breaks). This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/41-Mt-Moriah-4049

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.12967856390887&lat=44.337714919809116#.VwxsgtT3aK0

=== What to Bring ===


We might still need traction - either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike: 

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at Stony Brook Trailhead which is located on the east side of Route 16 south of Gorham. According to Google Maps this spot is about 179 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 59 minutes to drive there.

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.how_to_find_us: Gray Toyota Highlander or Maroon Honda Accord.
results.name: NH4K ... Moriah (INTERMEDIATE)

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

NEW !!!!!! PLEASE TAKE NOTE: The time has changed and sneakers are not recommended.
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking, Rolling terrrain

results.name: Sun @ Crosby

results.description:
What: We will walk along the fabulous Duxbury Park Beach for 8 miles round trip. This beach is flat with a lot of rocks so bring hiking boots just in case. You don't climb rocks, but you just walk on them. Some are larger than those in the picture below. Zig zagging can be done to partially avoid them.

If you want to carpool, put a message on the comment section.  If you want to carpool send the person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture, then send a private message.  Bring a lunch to have by the lighthouse off the beach.  Hopefully it won't be windy.

You will park in the lot on right as you drive in before this bridge (Powder Point Bridge).

 After the lighthouse, we will walk away from the ocean on the side of the dunes.. Plan for a steady pace of 2.5 to 3.0 miles per hour. We will stop at points to take short breaks as needed. Plan for up to four hours, but please don't sign up if you need to be somewhere else in the afternoon.

What to Bring: Hiking boots, water, snacks

Information: The Duxbury Beach Reservation, Inc. was formed inn 1975. It evolved from the Duxbury Beach Association, which was created in 1919 when a small group of summer residents led by Frederick S. Pratt bought the beach. The Reservation’s statement of purpose clearly defines the purposes of the charitable corporation: “. . . to restore and to preserve the beaches in so far as reasonably possible in their natural state as host to marine life, native and migratory birds and indigenous vegetation, as barrier beaches for the protection of Duxbury and Kingston and as a priceless environmental asset to the Commonwealth and the nation; and to operate for the benefit of the people of Duxbury and the general public a public recreational beach with all necessary and incidental facilities, while preserving the right to limit and regulate such use so as to be consistent with the corporation’s primary ecological objective.

Since its incorporation in 1975, the Reservation has taken its mission very seriously. To maintain a barrier against the sea, it has added sand to the beach in two dune projects and numerous repairs, then stabilized the new sand with fencing and beach grass. To preserve the natural heritage of the beach, it has developed comprehensive programs to protect vegetation and wildlife. To operate a public recreational beach within the confines of these ecological objectives, as well as state and federal regulations, the Reservation has always relied on the cooperation of beach goers and the assistance of the town of Duxbury.

Once you register on Southborough Recreation Sports Meetup you can RSVP to play in all the Meetups you want. The $15 per month fee will be collected when you show up to play and will cover you for that month.

Doubles, Mixed Doubles, Singles matches will be played on outdoor hard-courts. All levels 3.0 and higher welcome. You must be able to serve over-head, volley and rally. New tennis balls for each court will be provided.

Rain and/or wet courts may force cancellation which will be communicated via e-mail as early as possible.

All players play at their own risk at all times.

This is an announcement for the BIKE-Arlington Tour planned for Sunday, May 15 organized by Arlington Bicycle Advisory Committee

Family-friendly bike ride - easy route, slow pace, informative!


https://sites.google.com/site/abacarlingtonmass/


Meet on Sunday, May 15, at 9:30 a.m. in Arlington Center, behind the Jefferson Cutter House in the large municipal parking lot (northeast corner of Mass Ave and Mystic St). 

The tour will end before noontime. Steady rain will cancel the bike tour. For additional local bicycling events during Bike Week, see baystatebikeweek.org.


The annual BIKE-Arlington Tour is scheduled for Sunday morning, May 15, 2016. This easy-paced bicycle tour around town is organized by the Arlington Bicycle Advisory Committee (ABAC) in local celebration of Bay State Bike Week. The family-friendly bike tour will pass on both the Minuteman Bikeway and local roadways, featuring informational stops along the way.


This year’s community bike tour will meet in Arlington Center and feature brief stops at the renovated Central Fire Station, the Gibbs School, the Alewife Station area (to point out bikeway connections), and the Alewife Brook Reservation. Along the way, the tour will travel on the new bike lanes on Mass Ave in East Arlington as well as part of the Alewife Brook Greenway path. The BIKE-Arlington will conclude with a reception hosted at the Regent Theatre (lower level), which is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year. 

The bike tour is FREE. Bicycle helmets are required, and all participants will be responsible for their own safety. Bring something to drink.

results.description:
Are You A Healer?  (Or Do You Want To Be?)

Reiki is energy healing that anyone can do with a class, an attunement to the energies, and a little practice.  The process of getting attuned also has the added benefit of helping to open up your own energy field and do some internal healing for yourself. 

Learn the art and science of Reiki in this full-day Reiki I Certification Training Program. 

You'll learn how to:

• Do healing work on yourself

• How to set good boundaries between you and others when doing your healing work

• The protection symbol and how to use it

• How to set a safe container for your healing work

• How NOT to be the "wounded healer" sometimes doing more damage than good

Through in-depth education and practice, you'll integrate the foundations of the Reiki process.

PLUS:  You'll also get:

• Additional Attunement and Certification in Angelic Reiki 

My Reiki Master Teacher channeled Angelic Reiki in 1990, combining the energies of traditional Reiki with the energies of the 7 Sisters of Angelic Reiki providing another layer of healing in your process. 

• Specialty Attunement for Magick Users

Did you know that the traditional Reiki attunements bind the symbols into your hands, forcing you to send all the energies that you send with your hands through the Reiki symbols.  This has caused no end of problems for some Magick users.  Some will throw off their attunements to avoid having to send other energies through the symbols.  I have developed a specialized attunement process that DOESN'T bind the symbols into the hands but still opens the pathways so that the energies can be used when you want them and ignored when you don't want them.

This special attunement is currently ONLY available through me.  

Why Take The Class With Me?

There are many people who teach Reiki.  Why would you take my class?  If the additional attunements above aren't enough to motivate you, then also consider this: most Reiki is taught in a vacuum - not taking into account other issues in the energetic world.  Because of this, traditionally trained Reiki users may not set solid safety containers for their work, or clear the space when they are done (leaving behind an icky energetic mess in their work space).  I teach the traditional Reiki AND additional energetic safety and hygiene practices to keep you and your clients safe.

PLEASE NOTE:  I only teach Reiki when I feel called to do so - which isn't often.  (The last time was probably 5 years ago.) So don't wait for this class to come around again, because it probably won't anytime soon.

results.description:
This month's speaker at SAB is an evolutionist; all are welcome. About the speaker: "Abby Hafer is a speaker, writer and humorist who particularly loves taking on Intelligent Design, Creationism, the politics surrounding them, and science denialism in general.

"A few years ago, she realized that Intelligent Design is a political pressure group, not a scientific issue. With this figured out, she realized that what we need are political-style arguments in defense of evolution. Her presentations contain bulletproof science, but are short, easy to understand, easy to repeat, and make the opposition look bad. She uses humor to puncture bad arguments. Crucial questions are raised, such as "Why do mens' testicles have such a bad location?" and "Who does God like better, us—or squid? Once she mentions testicles, everybody pays attention.

"Her book The Not-So-Intelligent Designer—Why Evolution Explains the Human Body and Intelligent Design Does Not which was published in 2015.

"Dr. Hafer has a doctorate in zoology from Oxford University, and teaches human anatomy and physiology at Curry College."

Learn more about Dr. Hafer from her appearance on the Nontheology podcast -- https://nontheology.com/2014/11/30/abby-hafer-unintelligent-design/. Learn more about Sunday Assembly Boston at boston.sundayassembly.com and https://www.facebook.com/sundayassemblyboston.
results.name: Sunday Assembly Boston: "Animals That Shouldn't Exist"

results.description:
My friends and Brunch  attendees have  Oooo'd and Ahhhhh'd at the paper flowers I made for Valentines and the Winter wonderland... and so FUN to do and they make a WOW statement for decorations for any party.   May is  great weather, and flowers all abloom in my yard , perfect for a garden party lunch.   Paper flowers can be made into different sizes , shapes, colors and honestly used for any occasion.  I love the smaller ones too that you wrap in green floral tape and put them in a vase.  So if you like to make things , have a birthday coming up for someone or just thinking of a party that you would make them for come try your skill at playing with paper :)  .  Little girls LOVE these!  I'm  going to hang them outdoors from trees or my Pergola (on my bucket list for this year over my farm table :)  , ( 4th of july, memorial day, easter, valentines day or even   halloween are great holidays to have these for decorations ) 

The PLAN:  You will learn how to make Beautiful colored tissue paper flowers in a few different designs and bring home  2 Large flowers and 2 smaller sized paper pom poms.  You will learn that the cutting of the paper in different shapes and how it is folded is what makes the flower (ex, Dahlia, Daisy, Sunflower) I will show you how to make those flowers, you pick the colors! The pom poms are easier, we'll start with those.

YOU BRING - good cutting scissors, a large garbage bag to take home your 2 big flowers (approx 16" diam, and 2 smaller pom poms).

I SUPPLY : The colored paper sheets, wire , floral tape, the location and table, Salad Parade, and the comical but crafty instruction :) Put them on wire, or hang them, your choice.

Be prepared to see the parade of color hanging from the trees while we have our lunch al fresco.  Can't wait to see all the colors!

LUNCH at NOON:  A parade of 4 Spring Salads, cool salads of various types, pasta, Cob Salad, Tom and Motz, basil,  my personal fav is my addicting chopped kale/green with apples, cranberries, pecans, a poppy seed dressing and blue cheese crumbles,, ? And We'll throw a few loafs of hot bread in , whats salad without hot BREAD anyways? Want Wine? BYOB, flavored ice tea will be provided.    No cooking, we will be busy being crafty!

NOTE-  I have decided to close this attendee number to 11 giving us more room because normally we fit 12 at the table to eat , but for crafting it might be too tight for someone on both ends. 

Cost to be crafty and fill your tummy - $25.00 Payment MUST be received by me asap for proper count and supplies  after your RSVP .   if you have RSVPs please be sure to send in your payment via Wepay .  I can't wait till two weeks prior for RSVP payment because it's not enough time to give someone else notice .    If you need to cancel for refund it must be outside 2 weeks from the event date to give proper notice for another member to attend.  Please be conscious of your RSVP scheduling.  thank you.

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿
results.name: Sunday Service

group.name: The First Spiritualist Church of Quincy

results.description: It's time for another FRAMINGCON game weekend. We start Friday night at 7:30 and play until late Sunday night. Since we usually stay up until at least 5:00 am, please do not arrive before 11:00 Saturday or Sunday. Dinner is provided on Saturday night. In addition to hundreds of games, there is a full sized pool table, and a 15-seat movie theater, for PS3 games like BUZZ and ROCK BAND. Saturday night, there is always a big party game, and all are encouraged to participate. There will be game demos as well. Crash space for people who want to stay over is available. Please contact me for more information. This event, as are all of my events, is open to all members of TABLETOP GAMING ALLIANCE, MENSA, UNITY GAMES, MEETUP, and more. FRAGS (Framingham Gamers) meets every Thursday night, and Tuesday night is movie night.

results.description:
Date changed because of predicted weather. The Harvard Square Business Association is proud to announce the 32nd Annual MayFair in Harvard Square happening on Sunday, May 1rd, 2015 from 12pm – 6pm. This annual spring time tradition features three stages of music, over 20 dance troupes, food, crafts, street art, a chalk art gallery and entertainment for all ages. Other highlights include Roaming Railroad train rides for the young and the young at heart, four beer gardens sponsored by Grafton Street Pub & Grill, FiRE + iCE, Alden & Harlow and The Sinclair, a children's activity area, Zumba lessons and over one hundred thousand happy people! In addition, MayFair features over 150 artisans and merchants selling arts and crafts, jewelry, and vintage clothing and boasts over 40 food vendors serving up international fare and local favorites!

Don’t forget to check out the annual Chalk on the Walk located on Church Street! Each year, the Cambridge Rotary’s Club’s Chalk on the Walk raises thousands of dollars for local charities. The art of chalk street painting has a history stretching back as far as the Italian Renaissance. Corporate and individual patrons sponsor painting squares and artists donate their creativity and talents. Prizes are awarded to the artists and proceeds from the event go to local Cambridge charities and scholarships.

- See more at: http://www.harvardsquare.com/32nd-annual-mayfair-harvard-square-sunday-may-3rd-2015-noon-600pm#.dpuf
results.how_to_find_us: We can meet outside of tasty burger. 40 John F. Kennedy St,
results.name: Mayfair Harvard Sq

results.description:
Bring any Android project you like, weather you are currently working on a side project as a hobby, have a new startup idea you want to work on, or just getting started on some tuts, and interested in learning more about Android in general! This is a good way to learn among your peers, network, meet some new people, get some help or feedback, and maybe even collaborate on a project together! So bring your energy, passion to learn, and most importantly bring your selves. All skill levels welcomed... 

If you are attending our HackNight for the first time. HERE ARE THE THREE THINGS YOU MUST DO BEFORE ATTENDING THE EVENT:

1.) BE SURE TO DOWNLOAD ANDROID STUDIO

2.) REQUEST AN INVITE TO OUR SLACK CHANNEL ANDROID BOSTON

3.) SIGN UP FOR OUR VIRTUAL STUDY IN JAVA (this has already started, yet there is still time to join)

Don't forget to follow us @AndroidBoston on Twitter, and share with your friends that you are attending #ABHN42!
results.how_to_find_us: Off of Porter Square T Stop (Redline), then take the bus or walk.

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$2/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $15/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.
results.name: Twice-Monthly Scrabble Meetup (Third Sunday of the Month)

results.description:
Hello all. 

We're heading to Harvard Square for the May meetup. Let's meet on Sunday May 15th at noon to introduce ourselves and talk photography. 

After 15 minutes or so of chatting, I'll announce the prompt, and we'll head out to find images in response. We will shoot on our own for a while, then re-convene to share images and talk about the challenge. 


After the meeting, we will discuss and share our images on meetup and instagram.

**There are a limited number of spots for this meetup. Guests are not allowed.

**Please join the waitlist if the event is full. Spots open up right before the meeting and it is very likely you will get in.

**For drivers to the meetup, parking is free in Cambridge on Sunday. All spots, metered or permit are open for free parking.


**If there is heavy rain on the day of the outing, I will probably cancel. Please check this page for updates in the case of bad weather. 

**If you need to contact me, please message me through meetup instead of commenting on this page. (My app doesn't update comments.)

See you there!

results.description:
Urban Hiking / Boston (Copley Square to the North End)

Sunday, May 15 @ Noon – Trinity Church

[SPACE IS LIMITED TO 12 (NO GUESTS), INCLUDING ME]

Let’s give the black flies a day off and meet in front of the Trinity Church in Copley Square.  From there, we’ll make our way down Commonwealth Avenue, the Public Garden, Boston Common, Government Center, (Haymarket will be closed), the waterfront and into the North End.

My intent is not to blast from one end to the other, but to walk at a leisurely pace and take in the sights, sounds, and smel…uh, I mean, aromas, of the city.  I will most likely want to grab a cappuccino at some point.  And if there is a shop you want to venture into, by all means go shop!

IMPORTANT:  Once we feel we’ve seen enough (!) and want to settle in for a drink and a meal, I’ve made 5:00 dinner reservations (under the name Tamara Huston) for TWO TABLES OF SIX (12 people) at Carmalina’s North End restaurant, 307 Hanover Street (cross between Richmond and Prince Street); tel:[masked] – see website for menu/prices, etc.

A torrential rain forecast cancels this event as I will not walk around town with an umbrella in my hands.  I’ll keep an eye out and if I decide to cancel the event/reservations, I will post as early as I can on Sunday morning.

Please wear comfortable shoes!

This event is listed with TWO groups, so the rsvp count will not be correct on both sites.

Any questions?  Please contact organizer at [masked] or call/text at[masked]-8364.

Organizer assumes no liability before, during or after this event.

results.description:
Small Doggy Playdates are held at The Meadows Pet Resort and Spa in Holliston, 140 Summer Street. We meet mostly every 3rd Sunday of the month, 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm.


The Meadows is a multi-million dollar pet resort. The resort provides us with a large, clean indoor room with windows, chairs, water bowls, and plenty of room for our small dogs to play and socialize. Your dog can run around and play with others, off leash, in a safe environment.  

• All small and toy breeds are welcome. We look forward to having owners of FRIENDLY, EASY-GOING small dogs (under 20 lbs), with GOOD DOGGY MANNERS come play and make new friends. Please be sure your small dog(s) is healthy, clean, spayed or neutered, flea-free, and up-to-date with shots. If your pup(s) shows aggression or excessively barks towards others, you may be asked to leave.

• Due to the increase in participation at our PlayDates in Holliston, parking has become limited. The Holliston Meadows staff has asked us to please park directly across the street at Fatima Shrine where there is ample FREE parking for all. 

• Due to some food allergy-prone dogs, please refrain from feeding your dog treats or snacks during the PlayDate. Their Moms and Dads will greatly appreciate this.

results.description:
This will be an intro session and we'll discuss some theory, and then get right into movement drills. We will be covering material from a Z-Health movement template call "R-Phase". The goals are restoring end ranges of motion in all joints, rehabilitating any stiffness/pain/movement compensations, and training the brain/nervous system to be smarter about movement - increase coordination, contractile capacities of muscles, etc. 

Come experience how this can help you move better and increase your athletic performance.  This system is designed to work for people across a broad spectrum, from sedentary folks to elite level athletes.  All skill levels are welcome.
results.how_to_find_us: 5 Basile Street, Roslindale MA 02131 (behind the Dragon Chef Restaurant off Washington St.) Located in the YMAA Boston Studio. Parking is allowed in front of the adjacent school on Sundays, and is free.
results.name: Show up and wear loose clothes

results.description:
This is the big one.  How do the mathematical laws which govern quantum mechanics allow for new algorithms and new complexity classes?  Somehow, the fundamentally "probabilistic" nature of QM is not simply classical probability, neither in the sense of "lacking knowledge of the truth" nor in the sense of "truly random processes".  The two features of complex probability amplitudes and entanglement of multiple particles are what takes us into a new realm.

NOTE: It seems to me that there is a lot of material to digest this time around, so I anticipate spending two meetings on this one lecture.  For example, Aaronson does not actually describe Shor's Algorithm in the lecture, but I'd love to try to go through it if others are interested.

We will be discussing Lecture 10: "Quantum Computing", from Scott Aaronson's lectures on quantum computing. Please feel free to come to this meetup, regardless of whether you attended any or all of the previous ones.

The lectures can be found here.

******************************************************

A NOTE ON THE LOCATION: For first-timers, getting into the building can be a bit tricky. See this page for a map and explanation.
results.name: A first look at Quantum Computing (Quantum Computing Study Group, Lec. 10)

results.description:
We want to make our services available to everyone. Some can’t spare the time for one of our standard appointments, or can’t afford even our low-cost/pay-what-you-can consultation option. Recognizing this, we will offer short, focused mini-consultations, including one herbal preparation, for free to all comers. This is your opportunity to talk with a practicing herbalist, share any health concerns you may have, and receive personalized education in the preparation and use of herbs.

Sunday, May 15th, 2016 
1:00pm – 5:00pm 
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The consultation and one preparation are free. (Donations are accepted.)

For this free clinic day, we cannot schedule specific individual appointment times – everything will be first come, first served. If we have a high turnout this may entail some wait time. We expect the mini-consultations themselves to run approximately 20 minutes each, plus 5-10 minutes for preparation of herbs.

Please spread the word! We would especially like to reach out to underserved individuals who would not otherwise have access to herbal medicine.

Please note: this is not a medical clinic: we are not doctors, we are not dispensing medical advice, and we are not diagnosing or treating any medical conditions. We are providing information and education from the perspective of traditional herbalism. The herbal preparations we provide are to be considered samples to aid in your personal investigation into the effects of herbs in your own body.

If you plan to come by, it helps us if you RSVP by filling out our contact form or emailing us at [masked].

http://commonwealthherbs.com/free-herbal-clinic/
results.name: Herbal Free Clinic Day

results.description:
Hi Urban Sketchers,

Let's head to North End Park this Sunday, May 15th to sketch! The plan is to meet at 1pm in North End Park (on the corner of Hanover St. and Cross St.)  We will then disperse to sketch for 2 hours, and meet back at 3pm to share our work.

There will be plenty of inspiration to sketch - the surrounding urban architecture, people, and the greenery in the park to name a few.

Here's some info on North End Park:

The North End Parks on the Rose Kennedy Greenway have reconnected Boston. Green space has been created in an area that was formerly an eyesore. It is also utilizing previously underutilized space as well as creating a beautiful segue into Boston as one enters via the Zakim Bridge and descends into the tunnel known as the “Big Dig”. With the dismantling of the old elevated Central Artery, the North End Parks now serve as a sun-splashed link between this historic neighborhood and the rest of the city.


Gustafson Guthrie Nichol Ltd[1] and Crosby Schlessinger Smallridge[2] designed North End Parks. The opening ceremony for the parks was held on November 5, 2007.

The North End Parks design concept features flexible spaces including green landscapes with a path system, plazas with pergolas and water features that run through both parks and appeal to a wide range of people, including North End residents of all ages and the thousands of tourists and Bostonians who visit each year. The enthusiastic involvement of the neighborhood and an engaging public process were essential in shaping the design of a new "front porch" for the North End.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at North End Park (corner of Hanover St. and Cross St.) - look for the sketchbooks :)
results.name: Let's Sketch North End Park!

Please note: this is not a medical clinic: we are not doctors, we are not dispensing medical advice, and we are not diagnosing or treating any medical conditions. We are providing information and education from the perspective of traditional herbalism. The herbal preparations we provide are to be considered samples to aid in your personal investigation into the effects of herbs in your own body.

If you plan to come by, it helps us if you RSVP by filling out our contact form or emailing us at [masked].

http://commonwealthherbs.com/free-herbal-clinic/

results.description:
Please join us for a pleasant afternoon of competitive party bridge.

Bertucci's has its own parking lot, a welcoming atmosphere, and hearty food (including all-you-can-eat salads and soups).

Please sign up by Saturday afternoon, the day before the game. If at least 5 players have not registered by then, the game will have to be cancelled for that week.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play. No formal training will be offered, but this is a social, casual event, and bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed at any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.

results.description:
This Sunday, we're excited to be joined by Catherine Dunphy , author of From Apostle to Apostate: The Story of the Clergy Project. 

Catherine is one of the original members of the Clergy Project and its former Executive Director. She is now Operations Manager and Contributor for Rational Doubt, a Patheos blog. Catherine was trained as a Roman Catholic Chaplain -- her journey out of faith began and ended while attending seminary. She was an atheist by the time she graduated with her Masters in Theological Studies degree in 2004. 

On Sunday, join Catherine for talk at the Hub about her new book, her work with the Clergy Project, and her own journey from Catholic chaplain to atheist activist. With music, food, poetry, discussion, and more.

results.description:
Instead of 1 book/month, I will do genres or themes instead so we don't miss out on all the awesome books.

https://www.goodreads.com/group/show/186788-boston-drunk-bookclub

For our May 2016 bookclub, I selected "Will Kill for Food".  If you found a book that you love, please leave comment or bring it to the bookclub to surprise us.

Grave Mercy (His Fair Assassin #1) by Robin 

LaFevers

Throne of Glass by Sarah J. Maas


Graceling (Graceling Realm #1) by Kristin Cashore 

The Hunger Games (The Hunger Games #1) by Suzanne Collins  

Grave Mercy (His Fair Assassin #1) by Robin LaFevers


Why be the sheep, when you can be the wolf?
Seventeen-year-old Ismae escapes from the brutality of an arranged marriage into the sanctuary of the convent of St. Mortain, where the sisters still serve the gods of old. Here she learns that the god of Death Himself has blessed her with dangerous gifts—and a violent destiny. If she chooses to stay at the convent, she will be trained as an assassin and serve as a handmaiden to Death. To claim her new life, she must destroy the lives of others.
Ismae’s most important assignment takes her straight into the high court of Brittany—where she finds herself woefully under prepared—not only for the deadly games of intrigue and treason, but for the impossible choices she must make. For how can she deliver Death’s vengeance upon a target who, against her will, has stolen her heart?


Throne of Glass Paperback by Sarah J. Maas


In a land without magic, where the king rules with an iron hand, an assassin is summoned to the castle. She comes not to kill the king, but to win her freedom. If she defeats twenty-three killers, thieves, and warriors in a competition, she is released from prison to serve as the king's champion. Her name is Celaena Sardothien.
The Crown Prince will provoke her. The Captain of the Guard will protect her. But something evil dwells in the castle of glass--and it's there to kill. When her competitors start dying one by one, Celaena's fight for freedom becomes a fight for survival, and a desperate quest to root out the evil before it destroys her world. 

Graceling (Graceling Realm #1) by Kristin Cashore 

has been able to kill a man with her bare hands since she was eight - she's a Graceling, one of the rare people in her land born with an extreme skill. As niece of the king, she should be able to live a life of privilege, but Graced as she is with killing, she is forced to work as the king's thug. 


When she first meets Prince Po, Graced with combat skills, Katsa has no hint of how her life is about to change.
She never expects to become Po's friend.
She never expects to learn a new truth about her own Grace - or about a terrible secret that lies hidden far away...


The Hunger Games (The Hunger Games #1) by Suzanne Collins 


The nation of Panem, formed from a post-apocalyptic North America, is a country that consists of a wealthy Capitol region surrounded by 12 poorer districts. Early in its history, a rebellion led by a 13th district against the Capitol resulted in its destruction and the creation of an annual televised event known as the Hunger Games. In punishment, and as a reminder of the power and grace of the Capitol, each district must yield one boy and one girl between the ages of 12 and 18 through a lottery system to participate in the games. The 'tributes' are chosen during the annual Reaping and are forced to fight to the death, leaving only one survivor to claim victory.
When 16-year-old Katniss's young sister, Prim, is selected as District 12's female representative, Katniss volunteers to take her place. She and her male counterpart Peeta, are pitted against bigger, stronger representatives, some of whom have trained for this their whole lives. , she sees it as a death sentence. But Katniss has been close to death before. For her, survival is second nature.

results.description:
“Model Minority”... what this is and how this label and perspective has been a disservice to the Asian American community....experienced through role playing and discussion.

“The essence of American racism is disrespect.” 

― Ta-Nehisi Coates, The Case for Reparations, www.theatlantic.com


Note: Each monthly meeting is a "stand alone" meeting. No previous, or future, meeting attendance is required. We are happy to have your participation at any meeting.

Past history of conversations, etc. (people have been asking…here it is for quick reference):

1.  Nov. 15, 2015: Continuum of Behaviors, used Waking Up White, and Finding Myself in the Story of Race by Debby Irving, role playing and discussion, 15 folks attended, </a>http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/226175264/

2.  Dec. 6: White Privilege, used Unpacking the Invisible Knapsack by Peggy McIntosh, 14 folks attended, <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/226789621/">http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/226789621/

3.  Jan. 17, 2016, Martin Luther King, Jr. and Non-Violent Actions, 7 folks attended, </a>http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/227258976/

4.  Feb. 21, Diversity and Gentrification of Neighborhoods, 11 folks attended, <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/228164463/">http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/228164463/

5.  Mar. 20, Overt and Covert Racism, Micro Aggressions, 12 folks attended, </a>http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/229056337/

6.  Apr. 24, Black Lives Matter, 13 folks attended, <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/229425665/">http://www.meetup.com/Antiracists/events/229425665/

***

Below is the general information about this discussion series, posted every month:


The mission of this monthly group discussion series is to promote awareness of inequality, to build community, and to develop skills that address dismantling racism and oppression within a diverse, compassionate, and culturally sensitive environment.

"A window of opportunity won't open itself." - Dave Weinbaum

Even those of us living in the suburbs care about, and have a role to play in, the anti-racism movement. From frustration, fear, and anger to empathy, passion, and solidarity, this work can bring up a lot for everyone. Our supportive group discussions can help us get some clarity, perspective, and encouragement through the process. We will focus on a different topic each meeting, sometimes including films and discussions about printed materials …encouraging member feedback to help guide future topics.

All are welcome: People of Color, white people…people new to this topic and those involved and active for many years. Come with questions and/or experience to share with others wanting to learn more.

Hosted by Deb and Carlin, members of Boston Knapsack Anti-Racism Group.

If interested, please join Knapsack and RSVP to this meeting date (with no further obligations). Please change your RSVP if your plans change and you can no longer come so we can plan accordingly.

Feel free to post questions here too. We look forward to hearing from you!

Parking is available on the street, and behind and beside the church. Come in the door at the parking lot side of the church, lower level.

Public transportation unfortunately does not go to Medfield.  But most likely someone going to the meeting would be available to give rides to/from the Framingham commuter train station, Riverside T station, or elsewhere. Leave a comment about your needs and we will try to get you to the meeting if you want to join us! Car-pooling rules!

Future 2016 dates: plan for 3rd Sunday of each month, same time. We will post here if that changes.
results.name: Anti-Racism in the ‘Burbs (Medfield, MA)

Hi Ladies!

Let's check out the Mayfair this weekend.  Here's a little blurb on what it is.....The Harvard Square Business Association is excited to announce the 33rd Annual MayFair in Harvard Square happening on Sunday, May 1st, 2016 from 12pm – 6pm. This annual spring time tradition features four stages of music, over 30 dance troupes, food, crafts, street art, a chalk art gallery and entertainment for all ages. Other highlights include Roaming Railroad train rides for the young and the young at heart, four beer gardens sponsored by Grafton Street Pub & Grill, FiRE + iCE, Alden & Harlow and John Harvard’s Brew House, a children’s activity area, aerobic bootcamps and over one hundred thousand happy people! In addition, MayFair features over 120 artisans and merchants selling arts and crafts, jewelry, and vintage clothing and boasts over 40 food vendors serving up international fare and local favorites! - See more at: http://www.harvardsquare.com/mayfair-has-been-postponed-may-15th-due-inclement-weather#sthash.vnI3ngUf.dpuf


We'll meet at 2pm at Park Restaurant for a drink so we can all gather.  We'll be leaving no later than 2:30 to explore the square.  There are numerous food vendors if anyone is hungry and lots of entertainment.

I will be presenting a workshop on foraging for edible wild plants and mushrooms this Sunday (May 15) at the Boston Public Market. This workshop will be followed by a wild edibles cooking workshop with chef/cookbook author Didi Emmons (with me assisting). While these programs are taking place at the Boston Public Market, they are not intended to induce you to buy wild edibles at the market (although you may find other recipe ingredients there), or to read a fancy restaurant menu better. To the contrary: the purposes of the workshop is to help you to find and gather the wild edibles yourself. If you already like being outdoors, knowing what you can nibble on, or collect for later eating, while you are out there can make your outdoor excursions even more fun. -- Russ Cohen NOTE: registrations for these events are directly through the sponsor, The Trustees of Reservations. results.description:
*** Event announcement. *** (This will later be a meetup with a host to be determined later... *** 

One of Boston's beloved choirs, the Back Bay Chorale in collaboration with the New Bedford Symphony Orchestra will present two stellar pieces sure to leave you singing: Beethoven's 9th Symphony and Bernstein's Chichester Psalms 


It's rare the Bernstein's Chichester Psalms is performed in Boston with a full orchestra but it will be presented with an amazing local orchestra and the Back Bay Chorale.

"Masterpieces of the 19th and 20th century are presented in this final concert of the season in collaboration with the New Bedford Symphony. Beethoven’s 9th Symphony with its moving “Ode to Joy,” based on Schiller’s poetry, combined with Bernstein’s Chichester Psalms, a musical resetting of beloved portions of the “Book of Psalms”, focuses on redemption, compassion, and human dignity.

This concert celebrates the end of the 100th anniversary season for the New Bedford Symphony, a vital contributor to the performing arts community in Greater Boston. We perform the concert twice, once at the spectacular Zeiterion Arts Center in New Bedford and once at Sanders Theatre in Cambridge."

This concert is expected to sell out. (The performance in New Bedford the night before is close to being sold out).  Please buy your tickets early.  Ticket prices start at just $27 ($5 discount to seniors and students.)

Tickets available here: http://bbcboston.org/performances/bernstein-beethoven/  Suggesting you select Balcony E as your first choice and Balcony F as your second choice (to keep us together as much as possibe, two price options).

** Please make sure your RSVP to this event is correct about 3-4 days before to help the host plan.  (You can change your RSVP as much as you like!)

And to get on BBC insider's email list, sign up here to find out about other concerts and next year's cool program...  https://backbaychorale.secure.force.com/signup ;
